mula_pali: 378. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme. Tena kho pana samayena dve pabbajitā – muṇḍiyo ca paribbājako jāliyo ca dārupattikantevāsī yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho te dve pabbajitā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘‘kiṃ nu kho, āvuso gotama, taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ, udāhu aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’’nti?
mula_english:
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One (bhagavā) was dwelling at Kosambi in Ghosita’s Park.

At that time, two renunciates (pabbajitā), Muṇḍiya and the wanderer (paribbājaka) Jāliya, a student of the wooden-bowl ascetic (dārupattikantevāsī), approached the Blessed One (bhagavā); having approached, they exchanged greetings with the Blessed One (bhagavatā).

Having exchanged courteous greetings and polite conversation, they stood to one side.

Standing to one side, those two renunciates (pabbajitā) said this to the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ): “Friend Gotama (āvusā gotama), is the soul (jīva) the same as the body (sarīra), or is the soul (jīva) something different from the body (sarīra)?”
commentary_pali: 378.Evaṃme sutaṃ…pe… kosambiyanti jāliyasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā. Ghositārāmeti ghositena seṭṭhinā kate ārāme. Pubbe kira allakapparaṭṭhaṃ nāma ahosi. Tato kotūhaliko nāma daliddo chātakabhayena saputtadāro avantiraṭṭhaṃ gacchanto puttaṃ vahituṃ asakkonto chaḍḍetvā agamāsi, mātā nivattitvā taṃ gahetvā gatā, te ekaṃ gopālakagāmaṃ pavisiṃsu. Gopālakena ca tadā bahupāyāso paṭiyatto hoti, te tato pāyāsaṃ labhitvā bhuñjiṃsu. Atha so puriso balavapāyāsaṃ bhutto jīrāpetuṃ asakkonto rattibhāge kālaṃ katvā tattheva sunakhiyā kucchismiṃ paṭisandhiṃ gahetvā kukkuro jāto, so gopālakassa piyo ahosi. Gopālako ca paccekabuddhaṃ upaṭṭhahati. Paccekabuddhopi bhattakiccapariyosāne kukkurassa ekekaṃ piṇḍaṃ deti, so paccekabuddhe sinehaṃ uppādetvā gopālakena saddhiṃ paṇṇasālampi gacchati. Gopālake asannihite bhattavelāyaṃ sayameva gantvā kālārocanatthaṃ paṇṇasāladvāre bhussati, antarāmaggepi caṇḍamige disvā bhussitvā palāpeti. So paccekabuddhe mudukena cittena kālaṃkatvā devaloke nibbatti . Tatrassa ghosakadevaputto tveva nāmaṃ ahosi. So devalokato cavitvā kosambiyaṃ ekassa kulassa ghare nibbatti. Taṃ aputtako seṭṭhi tassa mātāpitūnaṃ dhanaṃ datvā puttaṃ katvā aggahesi. Atha attano putte jāte sattakkhattuṃ ghātāpetuṃ upakkami. So puññavantatāya sattasupi ṭhānesu maraṇaṃ appatvā avasāne ekāya seṭṭhidhītāya veyyattiyena laddhajīvito aparabhāge pituaccayena seṭṭhiṭṭhānaṃ patvā ghosakaseṭṭhi nāma jāto. Aññepi kosambiyaṃ kukkuṭaseṭṭhi , pāvāriyaseṭṭhīti dve seṭṭhino atthi, iminā saddhiṃ tayo ahesuṃ. Tena ca samayena himavantato pañcasatatāpasā sarīrasantappanatthaṃ antarantarākosambiṃ āgacchanti , tesaṃ ete tayo seṭṭhī attano attano uyyānesu paṇṇakuṭiyo katvā upaṭṭhānaṃ karonti. Athekadivasaṃ te tāpasā himavantato āgacchantā mahākantāre tasitā kilantā ekaṃ mahantaṃ vaṭarukkhaṃ patvā tattha adhivatthāya devatāya santikā saṅgahaṃ paccāsisantā nisīdiṃsu. Devatā sabbālaṅkāravibhūsitaṃ hatthaṃ pasāretvā tesaṃ pānīyapānakādīni datvā kilamathaṃ paṭivinodesi, ete devatāyānubhāvena vimhitā pucchiṃsu – ‘‘kiṃ nu kho, devate, kammaṃ katvā tayā ayaṃ sampatti laddhā’’ti? Devatā āha – ‘‘loke buddho nāma bhagavā uppanno, so etarahi sāvatthiyaṃ viharati, anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati taṃ upaṭṭhahati. So uposathadivasesu attano bhatakānaṃ pakatibhattavetanameva datvā uposathaṃ kārāpesi. Athāhaṃ ekadivasaṃ majjhanhike pātarāsatthāya āgato kañci bhatakakammaṃ akarontaṃ disvā – ‘ajja manussā kasmā kammaṃ na karontī’ti pucchiṃ. Tassa me tamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ. Athāhaṃ etadavocaṃ – ‘idāni upaḍḍhadivaso gato, sakkā nu kho upaḍḍhuposathaṃ kātu’nti. Tato seṭṭhissa paṭivedetvā ‘‘sakkā kātu’’nti āha. Svāhaṃ upaḍḍhadivasaṃ upaḍḍhuposathaṃ samādiyitvā tadaheva kālaṃ katvā imaṃ sampattiṃ paṭilabhi’’nti. Atha te tāpasā ‘‘buddho kira uppanno’’ti sañjātapītipāmojjā tatova sāvatthiṃ gantukāmā hutvāpi – ‘‘bahukārā no upaṭṭhākaseṭṭhino tesampi imamatthamārocessāmā’’ti  kosambiṃ gantvā seṭṭhīhi katasakkārabahumānā ‘‘tadaheva mayaṃ gacchāmā’’ti āhaṃsu. ‘‘Kiṃ, bhante, turitāttha, nanu tumhe pubbe cattāro pañca māse vasitvā gacchathā’’ti ca vutte taṃ pavattiṃ ārocesuṃ. ‘‘Tena hi, bhante, saheva gacchāmā’’ti ca vutte ‘‘gacchāma mayaṃ, tumhe saṇikaṃ āgacchathā’’ti sāvatthiṃ gantvā bhagavato santike pabbajitvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇiṃsu. Tepi seṭṭhino pañcasatapañcasatasakaṭaparivārā  sāvatthiṃ gantvā dānādīni datvā kosambiṃ āgamanatthāya bhagavantaṃ yācitvā paccāgamma tayo vihāre kāresuṃ. Tesu kukkuṭaseṭṭhinā kato kukkuṭārāmo nāma, pāvāriyaseṭṭhinā kato pāvārikambavanaṃ nāma, ghositaseṭṭhinā kato ghositārāmo nāma ahosi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – ‘‘kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme’’ti. Muṇḍiyoti idaṃ tassa nāmaṃ. Jāliyoti idampi itarassa nāmameva. Yasmā panassa upajjhāyo dārumayena pattena piṇḍāya carati, tasmā dārupattikantevāsīti vuccati. Etadavocunti upārambhādhippāyena vādaṃ āropetukāmā hutvā etadavocuṃ. Iti kira nesaṃ ahosi, sace samaṇo gotamo ‘‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’’nti vakkhati, athassa mayaṃ etaṃ vādaṃ āropessāma – ‘‘bho gotama, tumhākaṃ laddhiyā idheva satto bhijjati, tena vo vādo ucchedavādo  hotī’’ti. Sace pana ‘‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’’nti vakkhati, athassetaṃ vādaṃ āropessāma ‘‘tumhākaṃ vāde rūpaṃ bhijjati, na satto bhijjati. Tena vo vāde satto sassato āpajjatī’’ti. Atha bhagavā ‘‘ime vādāropanatthāya pañhaṃ pucchanti, mama sāsane ime dve ante anupagamma majjhimā paṭipadā atthīti na jānanti, handa nesaṃ pañhaṃ avissajjetvā tassāyeva paṭipadāya āvibhāvatthaṃ dhammaṃ desemī’’ti cintetvā ‘‘tena hāvuso’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
378. Thus have I heard…pe… the Jāliya Sutta at Kosambī.

Herein is an explanation of words not previously [encountered].

"Ghositārāma" means in the ārāma made by the wealthy man Ghosita.

Formerly, it seems, it was called Allakapparaṭṭha.

Then, a poor man named Kotūhalika, going to the country of Avanti with his wife and children, because of fear of hunger, being unable to carry his son, abandoned him and went on. The mother, turning back, took him and left. They entered a cowherd village.

And then much rice-gruel (pāyāsa) was prepared by the cowherd, and they, obtaining the rice-gruel from there, ate it.

Then that man, having eaten a large amount of rice-gruel and being unable to digest it, died during the night and was reborn in that very place in the womb of a bitch, and became a dog. He was dear to the cowherd.

And the cowherd attended upon a private Buddha (paccekabuddha).

And that private Buddha, at the end of the mealtime, gave the dog a lump [of food] each time, and having aroused affection in the private Buddha, he went to the leaf-hut together with the cowherd.

When the cowherd was not present, at mealtime, he himself would go and bark at the leaf-hut door to announce the time [for alms], and even on the road in between, having seen fierce animals, he would bark and drive them away.

He, with a softened heart toward the private Buddha, at the end of his life, was reborn in the world of the gods.

There his name was indeed Ghosakadevaputta.

He, having passed away from the world of the gods, was reborn in Kosambī in the house of a certain family.

That childless wealthy man, having given wealth to his mother and father, adopted him as his son.

Then, when his own sons were born, he attempted to have him killed seven times.

He, because of his merit, not attaining death in even seven places, at the end, having his life saved through the cleverness of a certain wealthy man's daughter, in a later part, through the death of his father, having attained the position of a wealthy man, became known as the wealthy man Ghosaka.

Also, in Kosambī there were two other wealthy men, Kukkuṭaseṭṭhi and Pāvāriyaseṭṭhi; with this one, they were three.

And at that time, five hundred ascetics from the Himalayas, for the sake of appeasing their bodies, would come to Kosambī from time to time, and these three wealthy men, having made leaf huts in their own gardens, would attend upon them.

Then one day, those ascetics, coming from the Himalayas, tired and thirsty in the great wilderness, having reached a large banyan tree, sat down there, expecting support from the deity residing there.

The deity, having extended a hand adorned with all ornaments, gave them drinking water, beverages, etc., and relieved their weariness. These [ascetics], astonished by the power of the deity, asked: "What good deed, O deity, have you done, by which this success has been obtained by you?" The deity said: "In the world a Buddha named the Blessed One has arisen; he now dwells in Sāvatthī, and Anāthapiṇḍika the householder attends upon him.

He, on the uposatha days, having given only their usual food wages to his servants, has the uposatha observed.

Then one day, at midday, having come for breakfast, I saw some servant not doing any work, and asked: 'Why are people not working today?'

They announced that matter to me.

Then I said this: 'Now half the day has passed; is it possible to do a half-uposatha?'

Then, having informed the wealthy man, he said, 'It is possible to do it.'

I, having undertaken a half-day, half-uposatha, and having died that very day, have obtained this success."

Then those ascetics, "A Buddha, it seems, has arisen!" with joy and delight having arisen, though desiring to go to Sāvatthī from there, [thought]: "These wealthy men who are our supporters have done much for us. We will announce this matter to them also," and having gone to Kosambī, after being honored and respected by the wealthy men, they said, "We will go this very day."

"Why, venerable sirs, are you in such a hurry? Didn't you formerly stay four or five months and then leave?" And when this was said, they announced that event.

"Then, venerable sirs, let us go together!" And when this was said, "We will go, you come slowly," having gone to Sāvatthī, having gone forth in the presence of the Blessed One, they attained arahantship.

Those wealthy men also, with a retinue of five hundred carts each, having gone to Sāvatthī, having given donations, etc., and having requested the Blessed One for the sake of coming to Kosambī, having come back, had three monasteries built.

Among them, the Kukkuṭārāma was made by Kukkuṭaseṭṭhi, the Pāvārikambavana was made by Pāvāriyaseṭṭhi, the Ghositārāma was made by Ghositaseṭṭhi.

With reference to that, it was said: "He dwells in Kosambī, in the Ghositārāma."

"Muṇḍiya" – this is his name.

"Jāliya" – this also is the name of the other.

Since his preceptor wanders for alms with a bowl made of wood, therefore he is called Dārupattikantevāsī.

"They said this" means that, desiring to bring forward a dispute with an intention to scold, they said this.

Thus, it seems, was their [intention]: "If the Śramaṇa Gotama says, 'The life is the same as the body,' then we will bring forward this argument against him: 'O Gotama, in your doctrine, the being is destroyed right here, therefore your doctrine is a doctrine of annihilation.'"

"If, however, he says, 'The life is one thing, the body is another,' then we will bring forward this argument against him: 'In your doctrine, the form is destroyed, not the being.

Therefore, in your doctrine, the being becomes eternal.'"
Then the Blessed One thought, "These (people) are asking a question for the purpose of introducing a debate. They do not know that in my teaching there is a middle path (*madhyamā pratipadā*) without approaching these two extremes (*dve ante*). Come, having answered their question, I will teach the Dharma (*dharmaṃ deśemi*) for the sake of revealing that very path." Having thought this, he said, "Then, friend," and so on.

mula_pali: 379. ‘‘Tena hāvuso, suṇātha sādhukaṃ manasi karotha; bhāsissāmī’’ti. ‘‘Evamāvuso’’ti kho te dve pabbajitā bhagavato paccassosuṃ. Bhagavā etadavoca – ‘‘idhāvuso, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ, sammāsambuddho…pe… (yathā 190-212 anucchedesu evaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ). Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti…pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati , kallaṃ nu kho tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti. Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati, kallaṃ tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti. Ahaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, evaṃ jānāmi evaṃ passāmi. Atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmi – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vā…pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe…  tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati, kallaṃ nu kho tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti? Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati kallaṃ, tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti. Ahaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, evaṃ jānāmi evaṃ passāmi. Atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmi – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vā…pe… ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ  abhinīharati abhininnāmeti…pe… yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati, kallaṃ nu kho tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti. Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati kallaṃ tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti. Ahaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, evaṃ jānāmi evaṃ passāmi. Atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmi – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vā…pe….
mula_english:
379.
“Then, friends, listen and carefully attend to what I shall say.”
“Yes, friend,” the two renunciates replied to the Blessed One.
The Blessed One said this: "Here, friends, a *tathāgata* appears in the world, a worthy one, a perfectly awakened one...pe... (as in sections 190-212, so it should be expanded).
Thus, friends, a *bhikkhu* is perfected in morality...pe... attains to and dwells in the first *jhāna*.
Now, friends, if a *bhikkhu* knows and sees thus, is it proper for him to say: 'The soul (*jīva*) is the same as the body (*śarīra*)', or 'The soul is different from the body'?"
Now, friends, if a *bhikkhu* knows and sees thus, is it fitting for him to say: 'The soul is the same as the body,' or 'The soul is different from the body'?"
But I, friends, know and see thus.
And furthermore, I do not say, 'The soul is the same as the body,' or 'The soul is different from the body'...pe... attains to and dwells in the second *jhāna*...pe... the third *jhāna*...pe... the fourth *jhāna*.
Now, friends, if a *bhikkhu* knows and sees thus, is it proper for him to say: 'The soul is the same as the body', or 'The soul is different from the body'?" Now, friends, if a *bhikkhu* knows and sees thus, is it fitting for him to say: 'The soul is the same as the body,' or 'The soul is different from the body'?"
But I, friends, know and see thus.
And furthermore, I do not say, 'The soul is the same as the body,' or 'The soul is different from the body'...pe... directs and inclines his mind towards knowledge and vision...pe... commentary_pali: 379-380. Tattha kallaṃ nu kho tassetaṃ vacanāyāti tassetaṃ saddhāpabbajitassa tividhaṃ sīlaṃ paripūretvā paṭhamajjhānaṃ  pattassa yuttaṃ nu kho etaṃ vattunti attho. Taṃ sutvā paribbājakā puthujjano nāma yasmā nibbicikiccho na hoti, tasmā kadāci evaṃ vadeyyāti maññamānā – ‘‘kallaṃ tassetaṃ vacanāyā’’ti āhaṃsu. Atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmīti ahaṃ etamevaṃ jānāmi, no ca evaṃ vadāmi, atha kho kasiṇaparikammaṃ katvā bhāventassa paññābalena uppannaṃ mahaggatacittametanti saññaṃ ṭhapesiṃ. Nakallaṃ tassetanti idaṃ te paribbājakā – ‘‘yasmā khīṇāsavo vigatasammoho tiṇṇavicikiccho, tasmā na yuttaṃ tassetaṃ vattu’’nti maññamānā vadanti. Sesamettha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
379-380.

"Is it fitting for him to say this?" That is, is it fitting to say this for that faithful renunciant who, having completely fulfilled the threefold morality ( *tividhaṃ sīlaṃ*), has attained the first jhāna (*paṭhamajjhānaṃ*)?

Having heard that, the wanderers, thinking that because an ordinary person (*puthujjano*) is not free from doubt (*nibbicikiccho*), he might sometimes speak thus, said, "It is fitting for him to say this."

And then, "I do not speak thus," I know this as such, but I do not speak thus. Then, having done the preliminary work on the *kasiṇa*, through the power of wisdom (*paññābalena*), a great expanded mind (*mahaggatacittaṃ*) arose, thus I established the designation (*saññaṃ ṭhapesiṃ*).

"It is not fitting for him to say this," this is what those wanderers say, thinking, "Because he is one whose *āsavas* are destroyed (*khīṇāsavo*), whose delusion (*sammoho*) is gone (*vigata*), who has crossed over doubt (*tiṇṇavicikiccho*), therefore it is not fitting for him to say this."

The rest here is of evident meaning.

mula_pali: 380. …Pe…  nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāti. Yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati, kallaṃ nu kho tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti? Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati, na kallaṃ tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti. Ahaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, evaṃ jānāmi evaṃ passāmi. Atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmi – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vā’’ti. Idamavoca bhagavā. Attamanā te dve pabbajitā bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mula_english:
380. …He understands: ‘… there is no more for this state of being.’

Now of one who thus knows and thus sees, is it proper to say: ‘The soul (*jīva*) is the same as the body (*śarīra*)’, or ‘The soul (*jīva*) is different from the body (*śarīra*)’?” Now of one who thus knows and thus sees, it is not proper to say: ‘The soul (*jīva*) is the same as the body (*śarīra*)’, or ‘The soul (*jīva*) is different from the body (*śarīra*)’?”

“But I thus know and see, friend (*āvusā*).”

and I do not say that the soul (*jīva*) is either the same as, or different from the body (*śarīra*).’”

That is what the Blessed One (*bhagavān*) said.

and the two wanderers rejoiced at his words.
commentary_pali: 379-380. Tattha kallaṃ nu kho tassetaṃ vacanāyāti tassetaṃ saddhāpabbajitassa tividhaṃ sīlaṃ paripūretvā paṭhamajjhānaṃ  pattassa yuttaṃ nu kho etaṃ vattunti attho. Taṃ sutvā paribbājakā puthujjano nāma yasmā nibbicikiccho na hoti, tasmā kadāci evaṃ vadeyyāti maññamānā – ‘‘kallaṃ tassetaṃ vacanāyā’’ti āhaṃsu. Atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmīti ahaṃ etamevaṃ jānāmi, no ca evaṃ vadāmi, atha kho kasiṇaparikammaṃ katvā bhāventassa paññābalena uppannaṃ mahaggatacittametanti saññaṃ ṭhapesiṃ. Nakallaṃ tassetanti idaṃ te paribbājakā – ‘‘yasmā khīṇāsavo vigatasammoho tiṇṇavicikiccho, tasmā na yuttaṃ tassetaṃ vattu’’nti maññamānā vadanti. Sesamettha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
379-380.
There, is it now the right time to speak to him? The meaning is: is it fitting now to say this to that faithful renunciate who has completely fulfilled the threefold morality and attained the first *jhāna*?

Having heard that, the wanderers, thinking, "Since an ordinary person is not without doubt, therefore he might sometimes speak thus," said, "It is the right time to speak to him."

And further, "I do not say," meaning, "I know just this, but I do not say thus." Furthermore, he established the designation: "This exalted consciousness arose through the power of wisdom of one developing [insight] after performing the preliminary act regarding the *kasiṇa*."

"It is not the right time to speak to him"—this the wanderers [say], thinking, "Since he is one whose *āsavas* are destroyed, whose delusion is gone, who has overcome doubt, therefore it is not fitting to say this to him."

The rest here is but clear.

mula_pali: 1. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandaṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi. Suppiyopi kho paribbājako antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandaṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti saddhiṃ antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena. Tatra sudaṃ suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati; suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa  vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati. Itiha te ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā anubaddhā (ka. sī. pī.) honti bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mula_english:
1. Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One (bhagavā) was traveling along the main road between Rājagṛha and Nālandā with a large company of monks (bhikkhusaṅgha), with about five hundred monks.

Suppiya the wanderer (paribbājaka) was also traveling along the road between Rājagṛha and Nālandā, together with his pupil, the youth Brahmadatta.

There, it is said, Suppiya the wanderer spoke in many ways in dispraise of the Buddha, spoke in dispraise of the Dharma (dhamma), and spoke in dispraise of the Sangha (saṅgha). But Brahmadatta, the pupil of Suppiya the wanderer, spoke in many ways in praise of the Buddha, spoke in praise of the Dharma, and spoke in praise of the Sangha.

And so those two, teacher and pupil, with arguments directly opposed to each other, followed close behind the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ), followed closely (ka. sī. pī.) and the Sangha of monks (bhikkhusaṅghañca).
commentary_pali: 1. Tattha evanti nipātapadaṃ. Metiādīni nāmapadāni. Paṭipanno hotīti ettha paṭīti upasaggapadaṃ, hotīti ākhyātapadanti. Iminā tāva nayena padavibhāgo veditabbo. Atthato pana evaṃ-saddo tāva upamūpadesasampahaṃsanagarahaṇavacanasampaṭiggahākāranidassanāvadhāraṇādianekatthappabhedo. Tathāhesa – ‘‘evaṃ jātena maccena, kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ bahu’’nti (dha. pa. 53) evamādīsu upamāyaṃ āgato. ‘‘Evaṃ te abhikkamitabbaṃ, evaṃ te paṭikkamitabba’’ntiādīsu (a. ni. 4.122) upadese. ‘‘Evametaṃ bhagavā, evametaṃ sugatā’’tiādīsu (a. ni. 3.66) sampahaṃsane. ‘‘Evamevaṃ panāyaṃ vasalī yasmiṃ vā tasmiṃ vā tassa muṇḍakassa  samaṇakassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsatī’’tiādīsu (saṃ. ni. 1.187) garahaṇe. ‘‘Evaṃ, bhanteti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosu’’ntiādīsu (ma. ni. 1.1) vacanasampaṭiggahe. ‘‘Evaṃ byā kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmī’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 1.398) ākāre. ‘‘Ehi tvaṃ, māṇavaka, yena samaṇo ānando tenupasaṅkama, upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena samaṇaṃ ānandaṃ appābādhaṃ  appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ puccha. ‘‘Subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhavantaṃ ānandaṃ appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchatī’’ti. ‘‘Evañca vadehi, sādhu kira bhavaṃ ānando yena subhassa  māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa nivesanaṃ, tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’’tiādīsu (dī. ni. 1.445) nidassane. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, kālāmā, ime dhammā kusalā vā akusalā vāti? Akusalā, bhante. Sāvajjā vā anavajjā vāti? Sāvajjā, bhante. Viññugarahitā vā viññuppasatthā vāti? Viññugarahitā, bhante. Samattā samādinnā ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattanti no vā, kathaṃ vo ettha hotīti? Samattā, bhante, samādinnā ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattanti, evaṃ no ettha hotī’’tiādīsu (a. ni. 3.66) avadhāraṇe. Svāyamidha ākāranidassanāvadhāraṇesu daṭṭhabbo. Tattha ākāratthena evaṃ-saddena etamatthaṃ dīpeti, nānānayanipuṇamanekajjhāsayasamuṭṭhānaṃ, atthabyañjanasampannaṃ, vividhapāṭihāriyaṃ, dhammatthadesanāpaṭivedhagambhīraṃ, sabbasattānaṃ sakasakabhāsānurūpato sotapathamāgacchantaṃ tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ sabbappakārena ko samattho viññātuṃ, sabbathāmena pana sotukāmataṃ janetvāpi ‘evaṃ me sutaṃ’ mayāpi ekenākārena sutanti. Nidassanatthena – ‘‘nāhaṃ sayambhū, na mayā idaṃ sacchikata’’nti attānaṃ parimocento – ‘evaṃ me sutaṃ’, ‘mayāpi evaṃ suta’nti idāni vattabbaṃ sakalaṃ suttaṃ nidasseti. Avadhāraṇatthena – ‘‘etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, mama sāvakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bahussutānaṃ yadidaṃ ānando, gatimantānaṃ, satimantānaṃ, dhitimantānaṃ, upaṭṭhākānaṃ yadidaṃ  ānando’’ti (a. ni. 1.223). Evaṃ bhagavatā – ‘‘āyasmā ānando atthakusalo, dhammakusalo, byañjanakusalo, niruttikusalo, pubbāparakusalo’’ti (a. ni. 5.169). Evaṃ dhammasenāpatinā ca pasatthabhāvānurūpaṃ attano dhāraṇabalaṃ dassento sattānaṃ sotukāmataṃ janeti – ‘evaṃ me sutaṃ’, tañca kho atthato vā byañjanato vā anūnamanadhikaṃ, evameva na aññathā daṭṭhabba’’nti. Me-saddo tīsu atthesu dissati. Tathā hissa – ‘‘gāthābhigītaṃ me abhojaneyya’’ntiādīsu (su. ni. 81) mayāti attho. ‘‘Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetū’’tiādīsu (saṃ. ni. 4.88) mayhanti attho. ‘‘Dhammadāyādā me, bhikkhave , bhavathā’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 1.29) mamāti attho. Idha pana mayā sutanti ca, mama sutanti ca atthadvaye yujjati. Sutanti ayaṃ suta-saddo saupasaggo ca anupasaggo ca – gamanavissutakilinna-upacitānuyoga-sotaviññeyya-sotadvārānusāra-viññātādianekatthappabhedo, tathā hissa ‘‘senāya pasuto’’tiādīsu gacchantoti attho. ‘‘Sutadhammassa passato’’tiādīsu (udā. 11) vissutadhammassāti attho. ‘‘Avassutā avassutassā’’tiādīsu (pāci. 657) kilinnākilinnassāti attho. ‘‘Tumhehi puññaṃ pasutaṃ anappaka’’ntiādīsu (khu. pā. 7.12) upacitanti attho. ‘‘Ye jhānapasutā dhīrā’’tiādīsu (dha. pa. 181) jhānānuyuttāti attho. ‘Diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ muta’ntiādīsu (ma. ni. 1.241) sotaviññeyyanti attho. ‘‘Sutadharo sutasannicayo’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 1.339) sotadvārānusāraviññātadharoti attho. Idha panassa sotadvārānusārena upadhāritanti vā upadhāraṇanti vāti attho. ‘Me’ saddassa hi ‘mayā’ti atthe sati ‘evaṃ mayā sutaṃ’ sotadvārānusārena upadhāritanti yujjati. ‘Mamā’ti atthe sati evaṃ mama sutaṃ sotadvārānusārena upadhāraṇanti yujjati. Evametesu tīsu padesu evanti sotaviññāṇādiviññāṇakiccanidassanaṃ. Meti vuttaviññāṇasamaṅgipuggalanidassanaṃ. Sutanti assavanabhāvapaṭikkhepato anūnādhikāviparītaggahaṇanidassanaṃ. Tathā evanti tassā sotadvārānusārena pavattāya viññāṇavīthiyā nānappakārena ārammaṇe pavattibhāvappakāsanaṃ. Meti attappakāsanaṃ. Sutanti dhammappakāsanaṃ. Ayañhettha saṅkhepo  – ‘‘nānappakārena ārammaṇe pavattāya viññāṇavīthiyā mayā na aññaṃ kataṃ, idaṃ pana kataṃ, ayaṃ dhammo suto’’ti. Tathā evanti niddisitabbadhammappakāsanaṃ. Meti puggalappakāsanaṃ. Sutanti puggalakiccappakāsanaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti. ‘‘Yaṃ suttaṃ niddisissāmi, taṃ mayā evaṃ suta’’nti. Tathā evanti yassa cittasantānassa nānākārappavattiyā nānatthabyañjanaggahaṇaṃ hoti, tassa nānākāraniddeso. Evanti hi ayamākārapaññatti. Meti kattuniddeso. Sutanti visayaniddeso. Ettāvatā nānākārappavattena  cittasantānena taṃ samaṅgino kattu visayaggahaṇasanniṭṭhānaṃ kataṃ hoti. Athavā evanti puggalakiccaniddeso. Sutanti viññāṇakiccaniddeso. Meti ubhayakiccayuttapuggalaniddeso. Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepo, ‘‘mayā savanakiccaviññāṇasamaṅginā puggalena viññāṇavasena laddhasavanakiccavohārena suta’’nti. Tattha evanti ca meti ca saccikaṭṭhaparamatthavasena avijjamānapaññatti. Kiñhettha taṃ paramatthato atthi, yaṃ evanti vā meti vā niddesaṃ labhetha? Sutanti vijjamānapaññatti. Yañhi taṃ ettha sotena upaladdhaṃ, taṃ paramatthato vijjamānanti. Tathā ‘eva’nti ca, meti ca, taṃ taṃ upādāya vattabbato upādāpaññatti. ‘Suta’nti diṭṭhādīni upanidhāya vattabbato upanidhāpaññatti. Ettha ca evanti vacanena asammohaṃ dīpeti. Na hi sammūḷho nānappakārapaṭivedhasamattho hoti. ‘Suta’nti vacanena sutassa asammosaṃ dīpeti. Yassa hi sutaṃ sammuṭṭhaṃ hoti, na so kālantarena mayā sutanti paṭijānāti. Iccassa asammohena paññāsiddhi, asammosena pana satisiddhi. Tattha paññāpubbaṅgamāya satiyā byañjanāvadhāraṇasamatthatā, satipubbaṅgamāya paññāya atthapaṭivedhasamatthatā. Tadubhayasamatthatāyogena atthabyañjanasampannassa dhammakosassa anupālanasamatthato dhammabhaṇḍāgārikattasiddhi. Aparo nayo, evanti vacanena yoniso manasikāraṃ dīpeti. Ayoniso manasikaroto hi nānappakārapaṭivedhābhāvato. Sutanti vacanena avikkhepaṃ dīpeti, vikkhittacittassa savanābhāvato. Tathā hi vikkhittacitto puggalo sabbasampattiyā vuccamānopi  ‘‘na mayā sutaṃ, puna bhaṇathā’’ti bhaṇati. Yoniso manasikārena cettha attasammāpaṇidhiṃ pubbe ca katapuññataṃ sādheti, sammā appaṇihitattassa pubbe akatapuññassa vā tadabhāvato. Avikkhepena saddhammassavanaṃ sappurisūpanissayañca sādheti. Na hi vikkhittacitto sotuṃ sakkoti, na ca sappurise anupassayamānassa savanaṃ atthīti. Aparo  nayo, yasmā evanti yassa cittasantānassa nānākārappavattiyā nānatthabyañjanaggahaṇaṃ hoti, tassa nānākāraniddesoti vuttaṃ, so ca evaṃ bhaddako ākāro na sammāappaṇihitattano pubbe akatapuññassa vā hoti, tasmā evanti iminā bhaddakenākārena pacchimacakkadvayasampattimattano dīpeti. Sutanti savanayogena purimacakkadvayasampattiṃ. Na hi appatirūpadese vasato sappurisūpanissayavirahitassa vā savanaṃ atthi. Iccassa pacchimacakkadvayasiddhiyā āsayasuddhisiddhā hoti, purimacakkadvayasiddhiyā payogasuddhi, tāya ca āsayasuddhiyā adhigamabyattisiddhi, payogasuddhiyā āgamabyattisiddhi. Iti  payogāsayasuddhassa āgamādhigamasampannassa vacanaṃ aruṇuggaṃ viya sūriyassa udayato yoniso manasikāro viya ca kusalakammassa arahati bhagavato vacanassa pubbaṅgamaṃ bhavitunti ṭhāne nidānaṃ ṭhapento – ‘‘evaṃ me suta’’ntiādimāha. Aparo nayo, ‘eva’nti iminā nānappakārapaṭivedhadīpakena vacanena attano atthapaṭibhānapaṭisambhidāsampattisabbhāvaṃ dīpeti. ‘Suta’nti iminā sotabbappabhedapaṭivedhadīpakena dhammaniruttipaṭisambhidāsampattisabbhāvaṃ. ‘Eva’nti ca idaṃ yoniso manasikāradīpakaṃ vacanaṃ bhāsamāno – ‘‘ete mayā dhammā manasānupekkhitā, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā’’ti dīpeti. ‘Suta’nti idaṃ savanayogadīpakaṃ vacanaṃ bhāsamāno – ‘‘bahū mayā dhammā sutā dhātā vacasā paricitā’’ti dīpeti. Tadubhayenāpi atthabyañjanapāripūriṃ dīpento savane ādaraṃ janeti. Atthabyañjanaparipuṇṇañhi dhammaṃ ādarena assuṇanto mahatā hitā paribāhiro hotīti, tasmā ādaraṃ janetvā sakkaccaṃ ayaṃ dhammo sotabboti. ‘‘Evaṃ  me suta’’nti iminā pana sakalena vacanena āyasmā ānando tathāgatappaveditaṃ dhammaṃ attano adahanto asappurisabhūmiṃ atikkamati. Sāvakattaṃ paṭijānanto sappurisabhūmiṃ okkamati. Tathā asaddhammā cittaṃ vuṭṭhāpeti, saddhamme cittaṃ patiṭṭhāpeti. ‘‘Kevalaṃ sutamevetaṃ mayā, tasseva bhagavato vacana’’nti dīpento attānaṃ parimoceti, satthāraṃ apadisati, jinavacanaṃ appeti, dhammanettiṃ patiṭṭhāpeti. Apica  ‘‘evaṃ me suta’’nti attanā uppāditabhāvaṃ appaṭijānanto purimavacanaṃ vivaranto – ‘‘sammukhā paṭiggahitamidaṃ mayā tassa bhagavato catuvesārajjavisāradassa dasabaladharassa āsabhaṭṭhānaṭṭhāyino sīhanādanādino sabbasattuttamassa dhammissarassa dhammarājassa dhammādhipatino dhammadīpassa dhammasaraṇassa saddhammavaracakkavattino sammāsambuddhassa vacanaṃ, na ettha atthe vā dhamme vā pade vā byañjane vā kaṅkhā vā vimati vā kātabbā’’ti sabbesaṃ devamanussānaṃ imasmiṃ dhamme assaddhiyaṃ vināseti, saddhāsampadaṃ uppādeti. Tenetaṃ vuccati – Ekanti  gaṇanaparicchedaniddeso. Samayanti paricchinnaniddeso. Ekaṃ samayanti aniyamitaparidīpanaṃ. Tattha samayasaddo – Tathā hissa – ‘‘appevanāma svepi upasaṅkameyyāma kālañca samayañca upādāyā’’ti evamādīsu (dī. ni. 1.447) samavāyo attho. ‘‘Ekova kho bhikkhave, khaṇo ca samayo ca brahmacariyavāsāyā’’tiādīsu (a. ni. 8.29) khaṇo. ‘‘Uṇhasamayo pariḷāhasamayo’’tiādīsu (pāci. 358) kālo. ‘‘Mahāsamayo pavanasmi’’ntiādīsu (dī. ni. 2.332) samūho. ‘‘Samayopi kho te, bhaddāli, appaṭividdho ahosi, bhagavā kho  sāvatthiyaṃ viharati, bhagavāpi maṃ jānissati, bhaddāli nāma bhikkhu satthusāsane sikkhāya aparipūrakārī’ti. Ayampi kho, te bhaddāli, samayo appaṭividdho ahosī’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 2.135) hetu. ‘‘Tena kho pana samayena uggahamāno paribbājako samaṇamuṇḍikāputto samayappavādake tindukācīre ekasālake mallikāya ārāme paṭivasatī’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 2.260) diṭṭhi. Tattha kiñcāpi etesu saṃvaccharādīsu samayesu yaṃ yaṃ suttaṃ yasmiṃ yasmiṃ saṃvacchare utumhi māse pakkhe rattibhāge vā divasabhāge vā vuttaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ therassa suviditaṃ suvavatthāpitaṃ paññāya. Yasmā pana – ‘‘evaṃ me sutaṃ’’ asukasaṃvacchare asukautumhi asukamāse asukapakkhe asukarattibhāge asukadivasabhāge vāti evaṃ vutte na sakkā sukhena  dhāretuṃ vā uddisituṃ vā uddisāpetuṃ vā, bahu ca vattabbaṃ hoti, tasmā ekeneva padena tamatthaṃ samodhānetvā ‘‘ekaṃ samaya’’nti āha. Ye vā ime gabbhokkantisamayo, jātisamayo, saṃvegasamayo, abhinikkhamanasamayo, dukkarakārikasamayo, māravijayasamayo, abhisambodhisamayo diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārasamayo, desanāsamayo, parinibbānasamayoti, evamādayo bhagavato devamanussesu ativiya pakāsā anekakālappabhedā eva samayā. Tesu samayesu desanāsamayasaṅkhātaṃ ekaṃ samayanti dīpeti. Yo cāyaṃ ñāṇakaruṇākiccasamayesu karuṇākiccasamayo, attahitaparahitapaṭipattisamayesu parahitapaṭipattisamayo, sannipatitānaṃ karaṇīyadvayasamayesu dhammikathāsamayo desanāpaṭipattisamayesu  desanāsamayo, tesupi samayesu aññataraṃ samayaṃ sandhāya ‘‘ekaṃ samaya’’nti āha. Kasmā panettha yathā abhidhamme ‘‘yasmiṃ samaye kāmāvacara’’nti (dha. sa. 1) ca, ito aññesu ca suttapadesu – ‘‘yasmiṃ samaye, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehī’’ti ca bhummavacananiddeso kato, vinaye ca – ‘‘tena samayena buddho bhagavā’’ti karaṇavacanena, tathā akatvā ‘‘ekaṃ samaya’’nti upayogavacananiddeso katoti? Tattha tathā idha ca aññathā atthasambhavato. Tattha hi abhidhamme ito aññesu suttapadesu ca adhikaraṇattho  bhāvena bhāvalakkhaṇattho ca sambhavati. Adhikaraṇañhi kālattho, samūhattho ca samayo, tattha tattha vuttānaṃ phassādidhammānaṃ khaṇasamavāyahetusaṅkhātassa ca samayassa bhāvena tesaṃ bhāvo lakkhīyati, tasmā tadatthajotanatthaṃ tattha bhummavacananiddeso kato. Vinaye ca hetuattho karaṇattho ca sambhavati. Yo hi so sikkhāpadapaññattisamayo sāriputtādīhipi dubbiññeyyo, tena samayena hetubhūtena karaṇabhūtena ca sikkhāpadāni paññāpayanto sikkhāpadapaññattihetuñca apekkhamāno bhagavā tattha tattha vihāsi, tasmā tadatthajotanatthaṃ tattha karaṇavacanena niddeso kato. Idha pana aññasmiñca evaṃ jātike accantasaṃyogattho sambhavati. Yañhi samayaṃ bhagavā imaṃ aññaṃ vā suttantaṃ desesi, accantameva taṃ samayaṃ karuṇāvihārena vihāsi, tasmā tadatthajotanatthaṃ idha upayogavacananiddeso katoti. Tenetaṃ vuccati – Porāṇā pana vaṇṇayanti – ‘‘tasmiṃ samaye’’ti vā, ‘‘tena samayenā’’ti vā, ‘‘ekaṃ samaya’’nti vā, abhilāpamattabhedo esa, sabbattha bhummamevatthoti. Tasmā ‘‘ekaṃ samaya’’nti vuttepi ‘‘ekasmiṃ samaye’’ti attho veditabbo. Bhagavāti garu. Garuñhi loke bhagavāti vadanti. Ayañca  sabbaguṇavisiṭṭhatāya sabbasattānaṃ garu, tasmā bhagavāti veditabbo. Porāṇehipi vuttaṃ – Api ca – Imissā  gāthāya vasenassa padassa vitthāraattho veditabbo. So ca visuddhimagge buddhānussatiniddese vuttoyeva. Ettāvatā cettha evaṃ me sutanti vacanena yathāsutaṃ dhammaṃ dassento bhagavato dhammakāyaṃ paccakkhaṃ karoti. Tena ‘‘nayidaṃ atikkantasatthukaṃ pāvacanaṃ, ayaṃ vo satthā’’ti satthu adassanena ukkaṇṭhitaṃ janaṃ samassāseti. Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavāti vacanena tasmiṃ samaye bhagavato avijjamānabhāvaṃ dassento rūpakāyaparinibbānaṃ sādheti. Tena ‘‘evaṃvidhassa nāma ariyadhammassa desako dasabaladharo vajirasaṅghāta samānakāyo sopi bhagavā parinibbuto, kena aññena jīvite āsā janetabbā’’ti jīvitamadamattaṃ janaṃ saṃvejeti, saddhamme cassa ussāhaṃ janeti. Evanti  ca bhaṇanto desanāsampattiṃ niddisati. Me sutanti sāvakasampattiṃ. Ekaṃ samayanti kālasampattiṃ. Bhagavāti desakasampattiṃ. Antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandanti antarā-saddo kāraṇakhaṇacittavemajjhavivarādīsu dissati. ‘‘Tadantaraṃ ko jāneyya aññatra tathāgatā’’ti (a. ni. 6.44) ca, ‘‘janā saṅgamma mantenti mañca tañca kimantara’’nti (saṃ. ni. 1.228) ca ādīsu hi kāraṇe antarā-saddo. ‘‘Addasa maṃ, bhante, aññatarā itthī vijjantarikāya bhājanaṃ dhovantī’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 2.149) khaṇe. ‘‘Yassantarato na santi kopā’’tiādīsu (udā. 20) citte. ‘‘Antarā vosānamāpādī’’tiādīsu  (cūḷava. 350) vemajjhe. ‘‘Api cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, tapodā dvinnaṃ mahānirayānaṃ antarikāya āgacchatī’’tiādīsu (pārā. 231) vivare. Svāyamidha vivare vattati, tasmā rājagahassa ca nāḷandāya ca vivareti evametthattho veditabbo. Antarā-saddena pana yuttattā upayogavacanaṃ kataṃ. Īdisesu ca ṭhānesu akkharacintakā ‘‘antarā gāmañca nadiñca yātī’’ti evaṃ ekameva antarāsaddaṃ payujjanti, so dutiyapadenapi yojetabbo hoti, ayojiyamāne upayogavacanaṃ na pāpuṇāti. Idha pana yojetvāyeva vuttoti. Addhānamaggappaṭipannohotīti addhānasaṅkhātaṃ maggaṃ paṭipanno hoti, ‘‘dīghamagga’’nti attho. Addhānagamanasamayassa hi vibhaṅge ‘‘aḍḍhayojanaṃ gacchissāmīti bhuñjitabba’’ntiādivacanato (pāci. 218) aḍḍhayojanampi addhānamaggo hoti. Rājagahato pana nāḷandā yojanameva. Mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhinti ‘mahatā’ti guṇamahattenapi mahatā, saṅkhyāmahattenapi mahatā. So hi bhikkhusaṅgho guṇehipi mahā ahosi, appicchatādiguṇasamannāgatattā. Saṅkhyāyapi mahā, pañcasatasaṅkhyattā. Bhikkhūnaṃ saṅgho ‘bhikkhusaṅgho’, tena bhikkhusaṅghena. Diṭṭhisīlasāmaññasaṅghātasaṅkhātena samaṇagaṇenāti attho. Saddhinti ekato. Pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehīti pañcamattā etesanti pañcamattāni. Mattāti pamāṇaṃ vuccati, tasmā yathā ‘‘bhojane mattaññū’’ti vutte ‘‘bhojane mattaṃ jānāti, pamāṇaṃ jānātī’’ti attho hoti, evamidhāpi – ‘‘tesaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ pañcamattā pañcapamāṇa’’nti evamattho daṭṭhabbo. Bhikkhūnaṃ satāni bhikkhusatāni, tehi pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi. Suppiyopikho paribbājakoti suppiyoti tassa nāmaṃ. Pi-kāro maggappaṭipannasabhāgatāya puggalasampiṇḍanattho. Kho-kāro padasandhikaro, byañjanasiliṭṭhatāvasena vutto. Paribbājakoti sañjayassa antevāsī channaparibbājako. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ‘‘yadā bhagavā taṃ addhānamaggaṃ  paṭipanno, tadā suppiyopi paribbājako paṭipanno ahosī’’ti. Atītakālattho hettha hoti-saddo. Saddhiṃ antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavenāti – ettha ante vasatīti antevāsī. Samīpacāro santikāvacaro sissoti attho. Brahmadattoti tassa nāmaṃ. Māṇavoti sattopi coropi taruṇopi vuccati. Tatrāti tasmiṃ addhānamagge, tesu vā dvīsu janesu. Sudanti nipātamattaṃ. Anekapariyāyenāti pariyāya-saddo tāva vāradesanākāraṇesu vattati. ‘‘Kassa nu kho, ānanda, ajja pariyāyo bhikkhuniyo ovaditu’’ntiādīsu (ma. ni. 3.398) hi vāre pariyāyasaddo vattati. ‘‘Madhupiṇḍikapariyāyotveva naṃ dhārehī’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 1.205) desanāyaṃ. ‘‘Imināpi kho, te rājañña, pariyāyena evaṃ hotū’’tiādīsu (dī. ni. 2.411) kāraṇe. Svāyamidhāpi kāraṇe vattati, tasmā ayamettha attho – ‘‘anekavidhena kāraṇenā’’ti, ‘‘bahūhi kāraṇehī’’ti vuttaṃ hoti. Buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsatīti avaṇṇavirahitassa aparimāṇavaṇṇasamannāgatassāpi buddhassa bhagavato – ‘‘yaṃ loke jātivuḍḍhesu kattabbaṃ abhivādanādisāmīcikammaṃ ‘sāmaggiraso’ti vuccati, taṃ samaṇassa gotamassa natthi tasmā arasarūpo samaṇo gotamo, nibbhogo, akiriyavādo, ucchedavādo, jegucchī, venayiko, tapassī, apagabbho. Natthi samaṇassa gotamassa  uttarimanussadhammo alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso. Takkapariyāhataṃ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti, vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ, sayaṃpaṭibhānaṃ. Samaṇo gotamo na sabbaññū, na lokavidū, na anuttaro, na aggapuggalo’’ti. Evaṃ taṃ taṃ akāraṇameva kāraṇanti vatvā  tathā tathā avaṇṇaṃ dosaṃ nindaṃ bhāsati. Yathā ca buddhassa, evaṃ dhammassāpi taṃ taṃ akāraṇameva kāraṇato vatvā – ‘‘samaṇassa gotamassa dhammo durakkhāto, duppaṭivedito, aniyyāniko, anupasamasaṃvattaniko’’ti tathā tathā avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati. Yathā  ca dhammassa, evaṃ saṅghassāpi yaṃ vā taṃ vā akāraṇameva kāraṇato vatvā – ‘‘micchāpaṭipanno samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakasaṅgho, kuṭilapaṭipanno, paccanīkapaṭipadaṃ ananulomapaṭipadaṃ adhammānulomapaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno’’ti tathā tathā avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati. Antevāsī panassa – ‘‘amhākaṃ ācariyo aparāmasitabbaṃ parāmasati, anakkamitabbaṃ akkamati, svāyaṃ aggiṃ gilanto viya, hatthena asidhāraṃ parāmasanto viya, muṭṭhinā sineruṃ padāletukāmo viya, kakacadantapantiyaṃ kīḷamāno viya, pabhinnamadaṃ caṇḍahatthiṃ hatthena gaṇhanto viya ca vaṇṇārahasseva ratanattayassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsamāno anayabyasanaṃ pāpuṇissati. Ācariye kho pana gūthaṃ vā aggiṃ vā kaṇṭakaṃ vā kaṇhasappaṃ vā akkamante, sūlaṃ vā abhirūhante, halāhalaṃ vā visaṃ khādante, khārodakaṃ vā pakkhalante, narakapapātaṃ vā papatante, na antevāsinā taṃ sabbamanukātabbaṃ hoti. Kammassakā hi sattā attano kammānurūpameva gatiṃ gacchanti. Neva pitā puttassa kammena gacchati, na putto pitu kammena, na mātā puttassa, na putto mātuyā, na bhātā bhaginiyā, na bhaginī bhātu, na ācariyo antevāsino, na antevāsī ācariyassa kammena gacchati. Mayhañca ācariyo tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, mahāsāvajjo kho panāriyūpavādoti. Evaṃ yoniso ummujjitvā ācariyavādaṃ maddamāno sammākāraṇameva kāraṇato apadisanto anekapariyāyena tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitumāraddho, yathā taṃ paṇḍitajātiko kulaputto’’. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsatī’’ti. Tattha vaṇṇanti vaṇṇa-saddo saṇṭhāna-jāti-rūpāyatana-kāraṇa-pamāṇa-guṇa-pasaṃsādīsu dissati . Tattha ‘‘mahantaṃ sapparājavaṇṇaṃ  abhinimminitvā’’tiādīsu (saṃ. ni. 1.142) saṇṭhānaṃ vuccati. ‘‘Brāhmaṇova seṭṭho vaṇṇo, hīno añño vaṇṇo’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 2.402) jāti. ‘‘Paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato’’tiādīsu (dī. ni. 1.303) rūpāyatanaṃ. Itiha te ubho ācariyantevāsīti evaṃ te dve ācariyantevāsikā. Aññamaññassāti añño aññassa. Ujuvipaccanīkavādāti īsakampi apariharitvā ujumeva vividhapaccanīkavādā, anekavāraṃ viruddhavādā eva hutvāti  attho. Ācariyena hi ratanattayassa  avaṇṇe bhāsite antevāsī vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, puna itaro avaṇṇaṃ, itaro vaṇṇanti evaṃ ācariyo sāraphalake visarukkhaāṇiṃ ākoṭayamāno viya  punappunaṃ ratanattayassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati. Antevāsī pana suvaṇṇarajatamaṇimayāya āṇiyā taṃ āṇiṃ paṭibāhayamāno viya punappunaṃ ratanattayassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘ujuvipaccanīkavādā’’ti. Bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā honti bhikkhusaṅghañcāti bhagavantañca bhikkhusaṅghañca pacchato pacchato dassanaṃ avijahantā iriyāpathānubandhanena anubandhā honti, sīsānulokino hutvā anugatā hontīti attho. Kasmā pana bhagavā taṃ addhānaṃ paṭipanno? Kasmā ca suppiyo anubandho? Kasmā ca so ratanattayassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsatīti? Bhagavā tāva tasmiṃ kāle rājagahaparivattakesu aṭṭhārasasu mahāvihāresu aññatarasmiṃ vasitvā pātova sarīrappaṭijagganaṃ katvā bhikkhācāravelāyaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto rājagahe piṇḍāya carati. So taṃ divasaṃ bhikkhusaṅghassa sulabhapiṇḍapātaṃ katvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto bhikkhusaṅghaṃ pattacīvaraṃ gāhāpetvā – ‘‘nāḷandaṃ gamissāmī’’ti, rājagahato nikkhamitvā taṃ addhānaṃ paṭipanno. Suppiyopi kho tasmiṃ kāle rājagahaparivattake aññatarasmiṃ paribbājakārāme vasitvā paribbājakaparivuto rājagahe bhikkhāya carati. Sopi taṃ divasaṃ paribbājakaparisāya sulabhabhikkhaṃ katvā bhuttapātarāso paribbājake paribbājakaparikkhāraṃ gāhāpetvā – nāḷandaṃ gamissāmicceva bhagavato taṃ maggaṃ paṭipannabhāvaṃ ajānantova anubandho. Sace pana jāneyya nānubandheyya. So ajānitvāva gacchanto gīvaṃ ukkhipitvā olokayamāno bhagavantaṃ addasa buddhasiriyā sobhamānaṃ rattakambalaparikkhittamiva jaṅgamakanakagirisikharaṃ. Tasmiṃ kira samaye dasabalassa sarīrato nikkhamitvā chabbaṇṇarasmiyo samantā asītihatthappamāṇe padese ādhāvanti vidhāvanti ratanāveḷaratanadāmaratanacuṇṇavippakiṇṇaṃ  viya, pasāritaratanacittakañcanapaṭamiva, rattasuvaṇṇarasanisiñcamānamiva, ukkāsatanipātasamākulamiva, nirantaravippakiṇṇakaṇikārapupphamiva vāyuvegakkhittacīnapiṭṭhacuṇṇamiva, indadhanuvijjulatātārāgaṇappabhāvisaravipphuritaviccharitamiva ca taṃ vanantaraṃ hoti. Asīti  anubyañjanānurañjitañca pana bhagavato sarīraṃ vikasitakamaluppalamiva, saraṃ sabbapāliphullamiva  pāricchattakaṃ, tārāmarīcivikasitamiva, gaganatalaṃ siriyā avahasantamiva, byāmappabhāparikkhepavilāsinī cassa dvattiṃsavaralakkhaṇamālā ganthetvā ṭhapitadvattiṃsacandamālāya dvattiṃsasūriyamālāya paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapitadvattiṃsacakkavattidvattiṃsasakkadevarājadvattiṃsamahābrahmānaṃ siriṃ siriyā abhibhavantimiva. Tañca pana bhagavantaṃ parivāretvā ṭhitā bhikkhū sabbeva appicchā santuṭṭhā pavivittā asaṃsaṭṭhā codakā pāpagarahino vattāro vacanakkhamā sīlasampannā samādhipaññāvimuttivimuttiññāṇadassanasampannā. Tesaṃ majjhe bhagavā rattakambalapākāraparikkhitto viya kañcanathambho, rattapadumasaṇḍamajjhagatā viya suvaṇṇanāvā, pavāḷavedikāparikkhitto viya aggikkhandho, tārāgaṇaparivārito viya puṇṇacando migapakkhīnampi cakkhūni pīṇayati, pageva devamanussānaṃ. Tasmiñca pana divase yebhuyyena asītimahātherā meghavaṇṇaṃ paṃsukūlaṃ ekaṃsaṃ karitvā kattaradaṇḍaṃ ādāya suvammavammitā viya gandhahatthino vigatadosā vantadosā bhinnakilesā vijaṭitajaṭā chinnabandhanā bhagavantaṃ parivārayiṃsu. So sayaṃ vītarāgo vītarāgehi, sayaṃ vītadoso vītadosehi, sayaṃ vītamoho vītamohehi, sayaṃ vītataṇho vītataṇhehi, sayaṃ nikkileso nikkilesehi, sayaṃ buddho anubuddhehi parivārito; pattaparivāritaṃ viya kesaraṃ, kesaraparivāritā viya kaṇṇikā, aṭṭhanāgasahassaparivārito viya chaddanto nāgarājā, navutihaṃsasahassaparivārito viya dhataraṭṭho haṃsarājā, senaṅgaparivārito viya cakkavattirājā, devagaṇaparivārito viya sakko devarājā, brahmagaṇaparivārito viya hārito mahābrahmā, aparimitakālasañcitapuññabalanibbattāya acinteyyāya anopamāya buddhalīlāya  cando viya gaganatalaṃ taṃ maggaṃ paṭipanno hoti. Athevaṃ bhagavantaṃ anopamāya buddhalīlāya gacchantaṃ bhikkhū ca okkhittacakkhū santindriye santamānase uparinabhe ṭhitaṃ puṇṇacandaṃ viya bhagavantaṃyeva namassamāne disvāva paribbājako attano parisaṃ avalokesi. Sā hoti kājadaṇḍake olambetvā gahitoluggaviluggapiṭṭhakatidaṇḍamorapiñchamattikāpattapasibbakakuṇḍikādianekaparikkhārabhārabharitā . ‘‘Asukassa hatthā sobhaṇā, asukassa pādā’’ti evamādiniratthakavacanā mukharā vikiṇṇavācā adassanīyā apāsādikā. Tassa taṃ disvā vippaṭisāro udapādi. Idāni tena bhagavato vaṇṇo vattabbo bhaveyya. Yasmā panesa lābhasakkārahāniyā ceva pakkhahāniyā ca niccampi bhagavantaṃ usūyati. Aññatitthiyānañhi yāva buddho loke nuppajjati, tāvadeva lābhasakkārā nibbattanti, buddhuppādato pana paṭṭhāya parihīnalābhasakkārā honti , sūriyuggamane khajjopanakā viya nissirīkataṃ āpajjanti. Upatissakolitānañca sañjayassa santike pabbajitakāleyeva paribbājakā mahāparisā ahesuṃ, tesu pana pakkantesu sāpi tesaṃ parisā bhinnā. Iti imehi dvīhi kāraṇehi ayaṃ paribbājako yasmā niccampi bhagavantaṃ usūyati, tasmā taṃ usūyavisuggāraṃ uggiranto ratanattayassa avaṇṇameva bhāsatīti veditabbo.

*Meti* and others are nouns.
In "he has undertaken," *paṭi-* is a prefix, and *hoti* is a verb.
In this way, the division of words should be understood.
In meaning, however, the word *evaṃ* has various meanings, such as comparison, instruction, praise, reproach, acceptance of a statement, mode, demonstration, and ascertainment.
Likewise, it was said, "Having been born thus, a mortal should do much good" (Dha.

3.66) In the sense of emphasis.

Here, it should be viewed as an instance of mode, illustration and emphasis.

Herein, in the sense of mode, he illustrates this meaning by the word "thus". [The meaning is that the Blessed One's word] is skillful in many methods (nānānayanipuṇa), arises from diverse inclinations (anekajjhāsayasamuṭṭhānaṃ), is endowed with meaning and expression (atthabyañjanasampannaṃ), possesses various marvels (vividhapāṭihāriyaṃ), is profound in teaching and penetrating ideas and meanings (dhammatthadesanāpaṭivedhagambhīraṃ), and comes to the ear of all beings (sabbasattānaṃ) in accordance with their own language (sakasakabhāsānurūpato). Who is capable of understanding it in every way (sabbappakārena)? However, by arousing the desire to hear in every way (sabbathāmena), [it is said] 'Thus I heard (evaṃ me sutaṃ),' and 'I also heard (mayāpi evaṃ suta) in one way (ekena ākārena.'

In the sense of demonstration, excluding himself by saying, "I am not self-become (nāhaṃ sayambhū), nor has this been realized by me (na mayā idaṃ sacchikata)," he demonstrates the entire *sūtra* (sakalaṃ suttaṃ) that is to be spoken now, [saying] "Thus I heard (evaṃ me sutaṃ)," "I also heard (mayāpi evaṃ suta)."

In the sense of emphasis, [it is said,] "Monks, this Ānanda is foremost among my disciples who are learned (bahussutānaṃ), endowed with *gati*, *sati*, and *dhiti*, and attendants (upaṭṭhākānaṃ)," (A.N. 1.223).

Thus, by the Blessed One: “The venerable Ānanda is skilled in meaning (*arthakusala*), skilled in Dharma (*dharmakusala*), skilled in expression (*byañjanakusala*), skilled in etymology (*niruttikusala*), skilled in what precedes and what follows (*pubbāparakusala*)," (A.N. 5.169).

Thus, the general of the Dharma (dhammasenāpatinā), showing his strength of memory (dhāraṇabalaṃ) in accordance with the commended state (pasatthabhāvānurūpaṃ), generates a desire to hear in beings (sattānaṃ sotukāmataṃ janeti), [saying] "Thus I heard (evaṃ me sutaṃ)," and "That, indeed, is neither less nor more in meaning or expression (atthato vā byañjanato vā anūnamanadhikaṃ), and it should be regarded exactly thus (evameva na aññathā daṭṭhabba)."

The word "me" (me-saddo) appears in three senses (tīsu atthesu dissati).

Thus, in passages such as "What has been earned by stanzas is uneatable by me (gāthābhigītaṃ me abhojaneyya)," (S.N. 81) the meaning is "by me (mayā)."

In passages such as "Venerable Sir (bhante), may the Blessed One (bhagavā) teach me the Dharma (dhammaṃ desetū) in brief (saṅkhittena)," (S.N. 4.88) the meaning is "to me (mayhaṃ)."

In passages such as "Monks (bhikkhave), be my heirs in Dharma (dhammadāyādā me)," (M.N. 1.29) the meaning is "of me (mama)."

Here, however, "by me heard (mayā sutaṃ)" and "my heard (mama sutaṃ)" are appropriate in two meanings (atthadvaye yujjati).

Here, *suta*, this word *suta*, with and without prefixes (*saupasaggo ca anupasaggo ca*)—[has] various kinds of meanings (anekatthappabhedo), such as going, celebrated, stained, accumulated, application, knowable by the ear, following the ear-door, known, and so forth—thus, in passages such as "Urging the army (senāya pasuto)," the meaning is "going (gacchanto)."

In passages such as "Of one who sees the heard Dharma (sutadhammassa passato)," (Udā. 11) the meaning is "of the celebrated Dharma (vissutadhammassa)."

In passages such as "Flowed out, of one who has flowed out (avassutā avassutassā)," (Pāci. 657) the meaning is "of one stained and unstained (kilinnākilinnassa)."

*‘me’ saddassa hi ‘mayā’ti atthe sati ‘evaṃ mayā sutaṃ’ sotadvārānusārena upadhāritanti yujjati*: ‘me’ means ‘by me’; thus when there is the meaning of ‘by me’, it is fitting [to say] ‘*evaṃ mayā sutaṃ*’ what has been recorded by a given series of consciousnesses ushered in by ear-consciousness.
*‘mamā’ti atthe sati evaṃ mama sutaṃ sotadvārānusārena upadhāraṇanti yujjati*: ‘mine’ means when there is the meaning of ‘mine,’ thus ‘*evaṃ mama sutaṃ*’ is fitting as the act of recording by a given series of consciousnesses ushered in by ear-consciousness.
*evametesu tīsu padesu evanti sotaviññāṇādiviññāṇakiccanidassanaṃ*: So as regards these three words, *evam* is the demonstration of consciousness’s function as ear-consciousness, etc.
*meti vuttaviññāṇasamaṅgipuggalanidassanaṃ*: and *me* demonstrates a person connected with the described consciousness.
*sutanti assavanabhāvapaṭikkhepato anūnādhikāviparītaggahaṇanidassanaṃ*: while *sutam* is a demonstration of grasping what is neither deficient nor excessive nor distorted, because it rejects the state of non-hearing.
*tathā evanti tassā sotadvārānusārena pavattāya viññāṇavīthiyā nānappakārena ārammaṇe pavattibhāvappakāsanaṃ*: Similarly, *evam* demonstrates that the kinds of cognizance beginning with hearing have actually occurred in the various ways with respect to an object by the description of the modes of the cognitive series 17 that has occurred by means of the ear-consciousness.
*meti attappakāsanaṃ*: *me* demonstrates an individual self.
*sutanti dhammappakāsanaṃ*: and *sutam* demonstrates an idea.
*ayañhettha saṅkhepo – ‘‘nānappakārena ārammaṇe pavattāya viññāṇavīthiyā mayā na aññaṃ kataṃ, idaṃ pana kataṃ, ayaṃ dhammo suto’’ti*: Herein this is the summary: “Nothing else was done by me with the cognitive series that has occurred in the various ways with respect to an object; but this was done; this idea was cognized.”
*tathā evanti niddisitabbadhammappakāsanaṃ*: Similarly, *evam* demonstrates something about to be demonstrated.
*meti puggalappakāsanaṃ*: *me* demonstrates a person.
*sutanti puggalakiccappakāsanaṃ*: and *sutam* demonstrates the person’s function.
*idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti*: This is what is said:
*‘‘yaṃ suttaṃ niddisissāmi, taṃ mayā evaṃ suta’’nti*: “That *sūtra* which I will indicate, that was thus heard by me”.
*tathā evanti yassa cittasantānassa nānākārappavattiyā nānatthabyañjanaggahaṇaṃ hoti, tassa nānākāraniddeso*: Similarly, *evam* is the various demonstration of one whose mind-continuum has a grasp of various meanings and expressions from the occurrence of various modes.
*evanti hi ayamākārapaññatti*: *evam* is indeed the description of this mode.
*meti kattuniddeso*: *me* demonstrates an agent.
*sutanti visayaniddeso*: *sutam* demonstrates an object.
*ettāvatā nānākārappavattena cittasantānena taṃ samaṅgino kattu visayaggahaṇasanniṭṭhānaṃ kataṃ hoti*: To this extent, by the mind-continuum that occurs in various modes, the establishment of the agent's grasp of the object is done by him who is connected with it.
*athavā evanti puggalakiccaniddeso*: Or, *evam* demonstrates a person’s function.
*sutanti viññāṇakiccaniddeso*: *sutam* demonstrates consciousness’s function.
*meti ubhayakiccayuttapuggalaniddeso*: and *me* demonstrates a person connected with both these functions.
*ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepo, ‘‘mayā savanakiccaviññāṇasamaṅginā puggalena viññāṇavasena laddhasavanakiccavohārena suta’’nti*: Herein, this is the summary, “By me, a person connected with consciousness functioning as hearing, by means of consciousness, by a term for a function of acquired hearing, [it was] cognized”.
*tattha evanti ca meti ca saccikaṭṭhaparamatthavasena avijjamānapaññatti*: Herein, the words *evam* and *me* are, in the true sense and ultimate sense, a description in terms of the non- factual.
*kiñhettha taṃ paramatthato atthi, yaṃ evanti vā meti vā niddesaṃ labhetha? sutanti vijjamānapaññatti*: What, herein, exists in the ultimate sense, that could obtain a demonstration such as *evam* or *me*? while *sutam* is a description in terms of the factual.
*yañhi taṃ ettha sotena upaladdhaṃ, taṃ paramatthato vijjamānanti*: Because, indeed, that which is perceived here by the ear is, in the ultimate sense, factual.
*tathā ‘eva’nti ca, meti ca, taṃ taṃ upādāya vත්තබ්ବతో upādāpaññatti*: Similarly, *evam* and *me* are a derivative description because they are stated derivatively upon this or that fact.
*‘suta’nti diṭṭhādīni upanidhāya vत्तබ්බతో upanidhāpaññatti*: while *sutam* is an appositional description because it that is, the heard, is so called in apposition to the seen and the rest.
*ettha ca evanti vacanena asammohaṃ dīpeti*: Here too, by the word *evam* he points out non-confusion.
*na hi sammūḷho nānappakārapaṭivedhasamattho hoti*: For someone who is confused is not capable of penetration of difference in kind.
*‘suta’nti vacanena sutassa asammosaṃ dīpeti*: By the word *sutam* he points out non-forgetting of what was heard.
*yassa hi sutaṃ sammuṭṭhaṃ hoti, na so kālantarena mayā sutanti paṭijānāti*: Because, someone whose hearing is forgotten, does not acknowledge after a time has elapsed: ‘I heard [this]’.
Through non-confusion, there is accomplishment of wisdom (*paññā-siddhi*); however, through non-forgetfulness, there is accomplishment of mindfulness (*sati-siddhi*).

There, with mindfulness preceded by wisdom, there is the ability to ascertain the letters (*byañjanāvadhāraṇa-samatthatā*); with wisdom preceded by mindfulness, there is the ability to penetrate the meaning (*attha-paṭivedha-samatthatā*).

Through the power of both these abilities, there is accomplishment of being a custodian of the *dharma*-treasure (*dharma-bhāṇḍāgārika-tta-siddhi*), due to the ability to preserve the *dharma*-treasury (*dharma-kośa*) which is endowed with meaning and letters (*attha-byañjana-sampannassa*).

Another way: by the word *evaṃ*, he indicates reasoned attention (*yoniso manasikāraṃ dīpeti*).

Indeed, because of the absence of various kinds of penetration, [that comes] from not giving reasoned attention (*ayoniso manasi-karoto hi nānappakāra-paṭivedhābhāvato*).

By the word *sutaṃ*, he indicates non-distraction (*avikkhepaṃ dīpeti*), because hearing is absent in one whose mind is distracted (*vikkhitta-cittassa savanābhāvato*).

For example, a distracted person, even when being told everything, says, "I did not hear it; say it again."

And through reasoned attention (*yoniso manasikārena*), here he establishes right self-direction (*attasammāpaṇidhiṃ*) and previously performed merit (*katapuññataṃ*), because of the absence of that (*tadabhāvato*) in one who is wrongly directed (*sammā appaṇihita-attassa*) and has not performed merit previously (*akatapuññassa vā*).

Through non-distraction (*avikkhepena*), he establishes hearing the true *dharma* (*saddhammassavanaṃ*) and reliance on true men (*sappurisūpanissayañca*).

For a distracted person is not able to hear, nor is there hearing for one who does not attend upon true men.

Another way: because by *evaṃ*, the grasping of various meanings and letters (*nānā-attha-byañjana-ggahaṇaṃ*) occurs to the mind-stream (*citta-santānassa*) with various kinds of activity (*nānākāra-ppavattiyā*), therefore it is said to be a designation of various kinds (*nānākāra-niddeso*). But that good form (*bhaddako ākāro*) does not occur for one who is wrongly directed (*sammā appaṇihita-attano*) and has not previously performed merit (*akatapuññassa vā*); therefore by this good form (*iminā bhaddakenākārena*) he indicates the attainment of the two subsequent wheels (*pacchimacakka-dvaya-sampattiṃ*).

*Sutaṃ* [indicates] the attainment of the two prior wheels (*purimacakkadvayasampattiṃ*) through the practice of hearing (*savana-yogena*).

Indeed, there is no hearing (*savanaṃ natthi*) for one dwelling in an unsuitable place (*appatirūpa-dese vasato*) or who is without reliance on true men (*sappurisūpanissaya-virahitassa vā*).

Through the accomplishment of the two subsequent wheels (*pacchima-cakka-dvaya-siddhiyā*), there is the accomplishment of purity of intention (*āśaya-śuddhi-siddhā hoti*); through the accomplishment of the two prior wheels (*purima-cakka-dvaya-siddhiyā*), there is purity of practice (*prayoga-śuddhi*). And through that purity of intention (*tāya ca āśaya-śuddhiyā*), there is accomplishment of manifest realization (*adhigama-byatti-siddhi*); through purity of practice (*prayoga-śuddhiyā*), there is accomplishment of manifest tradition (*āgama-byatti-siddhi*).

Thus, the speech (*vacanaṃ*) of one whose practice and intention are pure (*payoga-āśaya-śuddhasa*) and who is endowed with tradition and realization (*āgama-adhigama-sampannassa*), like the first light of dawn (*aruṇuggaṃ viya*) from the rising of the sun (*sūriyassa udayato*), and like reasoned attention (*yoniso manasikāro viya ca*) to wholesome action (*kuśala-kammassa*), he establishes the cause (*nidānaṃ ṭhapento*) in a suitable place (*ṭhāne*), [saying]: "*Evaṃ me sutaṃ* – Thus have I heard." He said, beginning with that, that it is fitting to precede the word of the Blessed One (*arhati bhagavato vacanassa pubbaṅgamaṃ bhavituṃ*).

Another way: by the word *evaṃ*, with this word that illuminates various kinds of penetration (*iminā nānāppakāra-paṭivedha-dīpakena vacanena*), he indicates the complete presence of his own skillful understanding of meaning and analytical insight (*attano attha-paṭibhāna-paṭisambhidā-sampatti-sabbhāvaṃ dīpeti*).

*Sutaṃ* [indicates] the complete presence of analytical insight and skillful expression of *dharma* in a way that illuminates the divisions of what is to be heard (*sotabba-ppabheda-paṭivedha-dīpakena dhamma-nirutti-paṭisambhidā-sampatti-sabbhāvaṃ*).

And *evaṃ*—illuminating reasoned attention (*yoniso manasikāra-dīpakaṃ*)—uttering the word *idaṃ*, he indicates: "These *dharmas* have been considered by me in my mind, [and] are well-penetrated by insight" (*ete mayā dhammā manasānupekkhitā, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā*).

*Sutaṃ*—illuminating the practice of hearing (*savana-yoga-dīpakaṃ*)—uttering the word *idaṃ*, he indicates: "Many *dharmas* have been heard by me, retained, [and] consolidated by word" (*bahū mayā dhammā sutā dhātā vacasā paricitā*).

By both of these, showing the completeness of meaning and letter (*attha-byañjana-pāripūriṃ dīpento*), he generates reverence in hearing (*savane ādaraṃ janeti*).

For indeed, one who does not respectfully listen to the *dharma* that is complete in meaning and letter (*attha-byañjana-paripuṇṇaṃ hi dhammaṃ ādarena assuṇanto*) is excluded from great benefit (*mahatā hitā paribāhiro hoti*); therefore, generating reverence (*ādaraṃ janetvā*), this *dharma* should be heard carefully (*sakkaccaṃ ayaṃ dhammo sotabbo*).

"Thus I have heard (*evaṃ me sutaṃ*)"—by this entire utterance (*iminā pana sakalena vacanena*), the venerable Ānanda, not appropriating to himself the *dharma* proclaimed by the *Tathāgata* (*tathāgata-ppaveditaṃ dhammaṃ attano adahanto*), transcends the plane of those who are not true men (*asappurisa-bhūmiṃ atikkamati*).

Acknowledging discipleship (*sāvakattaṃ paṭijānanto*), he descends to the plane of true men (*sappurisa-bhūmiṃ okkamati*).

Thus, he has his mind emerge from what is not the true *dharma* (*asaddhammā cittaṃ vuṭṭhāpeti*), [and] he establishes his mind in the true *dharma* (*saddhamme cittaṃ patiṭṭhāpeti*).

"All this has been heard by me, [and] is the word of the Blessed One" (*kevalaṃ sutam-ev-etaṃ mayā, tassa-eva bhagavato vacanaṃ*)—showing this (*dīpento*), he frees himself (*attānaṃ parimoceti*), he bears witness to the Teacher (*satthāraṃ apadisati*), he applies the Victor's word (*jinavacanaṃ appeti*), [and] he establishes the guide of the *dharma* (*dhamma-nettiṃ patiṭṭhāpeti*).

Moreover, "Thus I have heard (*evaṃ me sutaṃ*)"—not claiming it to be produced by himself (*attanā uppāditabhāvaṃ appaṭijānanto*), clarifying the prior utterance (*purimaṃ vacanaṃ vivaranto*)—"This has been received by me directly (*sammukhā paṭiggahitam idaṃ mayā*) from that Blessed One who is confident in the four grounds for confidence (*catu-vesārajja-visāradassa*), the possessor of the ten powers (*dasa-bala-dharassa*), abiding in the place of a bull (*āsabha-ṭṭhāna-ṭṭhāyino*), with the sound of a lion's roar and so forth (*sīhanāda-nādino*), the best of all beings (*sabba-sattu-ttamassa*), the lord of the *dharma* (*dhamm-issarassa*), the king of the *dharma* (*dhamma-rājassa*), the master of the *dharma* (*dhammādhipatino*), the lamp of the *dharma* (*dhamma-dīpassa*), the refuge of the *dharma* (*dhamma-saraṇassa*), the best wheel-turner of the true *dharma* (*saddhamma-vara-cakka-vattino*), the perfectly awakened one (*sammā-sambuddhassa vacanaṃ*)—"Here, there should not be doubt or uncertainty (*na ettha atthe vā dhamme vā pade vā byañjane vā kaṅkhā vā vimati vā kātabbā*)." He destroys the lack of faith in this *dharma* in all gods and humans (*sabbesaṃ deva-manussānaṃ imasmiṃ dhamme assaddhiyaṃ vināseti*), [and] he generates the accomplishment of faith (*saddhā-sampadaṃ uppādeti*).

Therefore this is said: *ekaṃ*—a designation that is a reckoning and a demarcation (*gaṇana-pariccheda-niddeso*).

*Samayanti*—a demarcated designation (*paricchinna-niddeso*).

*Ekaṃ samayanti*—an indefinite illumination (*aniyamita-paridīpanaṃ*).

There, although in these occasions beginning with year, whatever sutta was spoken in whichever year, season, month, fortnight, night or day, all that is well-known and well-established in wisdom to the Elder.
Because, however – "Thus I have heard" in such-and-such year, in such-and-such season, in such-and-such month, in such-and-such fortnight, in such-and-such part of the night, in such-and-such part of the day – when it is said thus, it is not possible to retain it easily or to recite it, or to have it recited, and much has to be said, therefore having summarized that meaning in one word, he said "On one occasion" ( *ekaṃ samayaṃ* ).
Or else what is meant is: among the Blessed One’s several times specially evident to gods and men and counted as Occasions, such as the Occasion of the Conception in the Womb ( *gabbhokkantisamaya* ), Occasion of the Birth ( *jātisamaya* ), Occasion of the Sense of Urgency ( *saṃvegasamaya* ), Occasion of the Renunciation ( *abhinikkhamanasamaya* ), Occasion of the Austerities ( *dukkarakārikāsamaya* ), Occasion of the Conquest of Māra ( *māravijayasamaya* ), Occasion of the Enlightenment ( *abhisambodhisamaya* ), Occasion of the Pleasant Abiding Here and Now ( *diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārasamaya* ), Occasion of the Teaching ( *desanāsamaya* ), Occasion of the Final Extinction ( *parinibbānasamaya* ).
Among these occasions, he indicates that the Occasion of Teaching ( *desanāsamaya* ) is called "one occasion" ( *ekaṃ samayaṃ* ).
And that occasion of compassionate action among occasions of knowledge and compassionate action, the occasion of practice beneficial to others among occasions of practice beneficial to oneself and to others, the occasion of Dhamma talk among occasions of two duties that should be done by those assembled, the occasion of teaching among occasions of practice of teaching, also with reference to those occasions, he said "On one occasion" ( *ekaṃ samayaṃ* ).
Why is the accusative case used here, as in the Abhidhamma, "when the realm of desire" ( *yasmiṃ samaye kāmāvacaraṃ* ) (Dha.
Sa.
1) and, in other Sutta passages, "when, monks, a monk is secluded from desires" ( *yasmiṃ samaye, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi* ) is the locative case used, and in the Vinaya, "at that time the Buddha, the Blessed One" ( *tena samayena buddho bhagavā* ) is the instrumental case used, and not having done so, why is the accusative case "On one occasion" ( *ekaṃ samayaṃ* ) used? There, it is so because the meaning is possible in different ways here and there.
For there, in the Abhidhamma and in other Sutta passages, the meaning of the locative case as a container and the meaning of characterization of one substantive by another substantive are possible.
Now the locative case is the time, and the Occasion is a collection; there, the nature of those things beginning with contact, which are stated there, is characterized by the nature of the Occasion, which is called a moment, an event, and a cause, therefore the locative case is used there to illuminate that meaning.
And in the Vinaya, the meaning of the instrumental case is that of cause and reason.
For that Occasion of the proclamation of the training precept, which is difficult to know even for Sāriputta and others, the Blessed One, making known the training precepts on that occasion, which was the cause and the reason, and expecting the cause of the proclamation of the training precept, dwelt there and there, therefore the instrumental case is used there to illuminate that meaning.
Here, however, and in other similar passages, the meaning of direct governance is possible.
For when the Blessed One taught this or any other Sutta, he dwelt on that occasion entirely in an abode of compassion, therefore the accusative case is used here to illuminate that meaning.
Therefore, it is said thus: But the ancients explain it, "At that time" ( *tasmiṃ samaye* ) or, "By that time" ( *tena samayena* ) or, "On one occasion" ( *ekaṃ samayaṃ* ), this is merely a difference in expression, the meaning is the same everywhere.
Therefore, even when "On one occasion" ( *ekaṃ samayaṃ* ) is said, the meaning should be understood as "At one occasion" ( *ekasmiṃ samaye* ).

But the pupil (*antevāsī*), as if warding off that peg (*taṃ āṇiṃ*) with a peg (*āṇiyā*) made of gold, silver, and jewels (*suvaṇṇarajatamaṇimayāya*), repeatedly speaks praise (*vaṇṇaṃ*) of the Triple Gem (*ratanattayassa*).

They followed (*anubandhā honti*) the Blessed One (*bhagavantaṃ*) closely (*piṭṭhito piṭṭhito*) and the monastic community (*bhikkhusaṅghañcāti*); not abandoning (*avijahantā*) the sight (*dassanaṃ*) of the Blessed One (*bhagavantañca*) and the monastic community (*bhikkhusaṅghañca*) from behind (*pacchato pacchato*), they followed (*anubandhā honti*) with continued deportment (*iriyāpathānubandhanena*), meaning they went (*anugatā hontīti*) having become those who looked after their heads (*sīsānulokino*).
Why did the Blessed One (*bhagavā*) set out (*paṭipanno*) on that road (*taṃ addhānaṃ*)? And why did Suppiya (*suppiyo*) follow (*anubandho*)? And why did he (*so*) speak dispraise (*avaṇṇaṃ bhāsatīti*) of the Triple Gem (*ratanattayassa*)? At that time (*tasmiṃ kāle*), the Blessed One (*bhagavā*), having dwelt (*vasitvā*) in one (*aññatarasmiṃ*) of the eighteen great monasteries (*aṭṭhārasasu mahāvihāresu*) in the vicinity of Rājagaha (*rājagahaparivattakesu*), early in the morning (*pātova*) having restored his body (*sarīrappaṭijagganaṃ katvā*) and at the time for the alms round (*bhikkhācāravelāyaṃ*), surrounded by the monastic community (*bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto*), wanders (*carati*) for alms (*piṇḍāya*) in Rājagaha (*rājagaha*).
Having made (*katvā*) an easily obtained alms-meal (*sulabhapiṇḍapātaṃ*) for the monastic community (*bhikkhusaṅghassa*) on that day (*taṃ divasaṃ*), after the meal (*pacchābhattaṃ*) having returned from the alms round (*piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto*), having made (*gāhāpetvā*) the monastic community (*bhikkhusaṅghaṃ*) bring his bowl and robe (*pattacīvaraṃ*) — "I will go (*gamissāmi*) to Nāḷanda (*nāḷandaṃ*)," he said (*iti*), having left (*nikkhamitvā*) Rājagaha (*rājagahato*) he set out (*paṭipanno*) on that road (*taṃ addhānaṃ*).
Also, Suppiya (*suppiyopi*), at that time (*tasmiṃ kāle*), having dwelt (*vasitvā*) in one (*aññatarasmiṃ*) of the monasteries (*ārāme*) for wanderers (*paribbājakā*) in the vicinity of Rājagaha (*rājagahaparivattake*), surrounded by wanderers (*paribbājakaparivuto*), wanders (*carati*) for alms (*bhikkhāya*) in Rājagaha (*rājagahe*).
He too (*sopi*), having made (*katvā*) an easily obtained alms-meal (*sulabhabhikkhaṃ*) for the wanderers' assembly (*paribbājakaparisāya*) on that day (*taṃ divasaṃ*), having finished his morning meal (*bhuttapātarāso*), having made (*gāhāpetvā*) the wanderers (*paribbājake*) bring his set of wanderer's requisites (*paribbājakaparikkhāraṃ*) - "I will go (*gamissāmi*) to Nāḷanda (*nāḷandaṃ*)," he said (*icceva*), not knowing (*ajānantova*) that the Blessed One (*bhagavato*) had set out (*paṭipannabhāvaṃ*) on that road (*taṃ maggaṃ*), he followed (*anubandho*).
If he had known (*jāneyya*), he would not have followed (*nānubandheyya*).
He, going along (*gacchanto*) unknowingly (*ajānitvāva*), having lifted his neck (*gīvaṃ ukkhipitvā*), looking around (*olokayamāno*), saw (*addasa*) the Blessed One (*bhagavantaṃ*) shining (*sobhamānaṃ*) with the glory of a Buddha (*buddhasiriyā*), like the shimmering crest (*sikharam*) of a moving golden mountain (*jaṅgamakanakagiriṃ*) enveloped in a red woolen blanket (*rattakambalaparikkhittamiva*).
At that time (*tasmiṃ samaye*), it is said (*kira*), having come forth (*nikkhamitvā*) from the body (*sarīrato*) of the Ten-Powered One (*dasabalassa*), six-colored rays (*chabbaṇṇarasmiyo*), all around (*samantā*) in an area the size of eighty hands (*asītihatthappamāṇe padese*) rushed (*ādhāvanti*), sped (*vidhāvanti*), like a bejeweled courtyard (*ratanāveḷa*) scattered with strings of jewels (*ratanadāma*) and powder of jewels (*ratanacuṇṇa*), like a spread cloth (*paṭamiva*) painted with jewels (*ratanacitta*) and gold (*kañcana*), like something sprinkled with the essence of red gold (*rattasuvaṇṇarasanisiñcamānamiva*), like something teeming with a hundred meteors (*ukkāsatanipātasamākulamiva*), like *kaṇikāra* flowers (*kaṇikārapupphamiva*) scattered without interruption (*nirantara*), like powder (*cuṇṇamiva*) of Chinese flour (*cīnapiṭṭha*) thrown (*khitta*) by the force of the wind (*vāyuvega*), and like a forest clearing (*vanaantaraṃ*) shimmering and sparkling with dispersed and scattered rainbows (*indadhanuvijjulatātārāgaṇappabhāvisaravipphuritaviccharitamiva ca*) was (*hoti*).
And furthermore (*ca pana*), the body (*sarīraṃ*) of the Blessed One (*bhagavato*), adorned (*anurañjitañca*) with the eighty minor marks (*asīti anubyañjana*), was like a blossoming lotus (*vikasitakamaluppalamiva*), like a lake (*saraṃ*) full of blooming *sabba* water lilies (*pāliphullamiva*), a *pāricchattakaṃ*, like a sky sparkling with starlight (*tārāmarīcivikasitamiva*), like the surface of the sky (*gaganatalaṃ*) mocking with glory (*siriyā avahasantamiva*), and as for his garland (*mālā*) of thirty-two excellent marks (*dvattiṃsavaralakkhaṇa*), shining with a fathom's extent of light (*byāmappabhāparikkhepavilāsinī*), having been strung together (*ganthetvā*), as if surpassing in glory (*siriṃ siriyā abhibhavantimiva*) the glory of thirty-two moon garlands (*ṭhapitadvattiṃsacandamālāya*), thirty-two sun garlands (*dvattiṃsasūriyamālāya*), [and] thirty-two emperor garlands (*dvattiṃsacakkavattidvattiṃsasakkadevarājadvattiṃsamahābrahmānaṃ*) placed in order (*paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapita*).
And those monks (*bhikkhū*) standing (*ṭhitā*) surrounding (*parivāretvā*) that Blessed One (*tañca pana bhagavantaṃ*) were all (*sabbeva*) of few wishes (*appicchā*), content (*santuṭṭhā*), fond of solitude (*pavivittā*), aloof (*asaṃsaṭṭhā*), exhorters (*codakā*), censors of evil (*pāpagarahino*), teachers (*vattāro*), tolerant of correction (*vacanakkhamā*), endowed with virtue (*sīlasampannā*), concentration (*samādhi*), wisdom (*paññā*), emancipation (*vimutti*), and the knowledge and vision of emancipation (*vimuttiññāṇadassanasampannā*).
In their midst (*tesaṃ majjhe*), the Blessed One (*bhagavā*), was like a golden pillar (*kañcanathambho*) surrounded (*parikkhitto*) by a red woolen rampart (*rattakambalapākāra*), like a golden boat (*suvaṇṇanāvā*) amidst a cluster of red lotus flowers (*rattapadumasaṇḍamajjhagatā*), like a tower of flame (*aggikkhandho*) encircled by a coral railing (*pavāḷavedikāparikkhitto*), or like the full moon (*puṇṇacando*) surrounded by the host of stars (*tārāgaṇaparivārito*), pleased (*pīṇayati*) the eyes (*cakkhūni*) even of the birds and beasts (*migapakkhīnampi*), much more (*pageva*) then [did he please] the eyes of gods and humans (*devamanussānaṃ*).
And on that day (*tasmiñca pana divase*), for the most part (*yebhuyyena*) eighty great *theras* (*asītimahātherā*) having made (*karitvā*) their cloud-colored (*meghavaṇṇaṃ*) rag robes (*paṃsukūlaṃ*) one-shouldered (*ekaṃsaṃ*), taking (*ādāya*) their walking sticks (*kattaradaṇḍaṃ*), like perfumed elephants (*gandhahatthino*) clad in solid armor (*suvammavammitā viya*), free from corruptions (*vigatadosā*), their corruptions ejected (*vantadosā*), their defilements shattered (*bhinnakilesā*), their tangles disentangled (*vijaṭitajaṭā*), and their bonds cut (*chinnabandhanā*) surrounded (*parivārayiṃsu*) the Blessed One (*bhagavantaṃ*).
He (*so*), himself (*sayam*) without lust (*vītarāgo*) [and] with those without lust (*vītarāgehi*), himself (*sayam*) without hatred (*vītadoso*) [and] with those without hatred (*vītadosehi*), himself (*sayam*) without delusion (*vītamoho*) [and] with those without delusion (*vītamohehi*), himself (*sayam*) without craving (*vītataṇho*) [and] with those without craving (*vītataṇhehi*), himself (*sayam*) without defilements (*nikkileso*) [and] with those without defilements (*nikkilesehi*), himself (*sayam*) awakened (*buddho*) [and] surrounded (*parivārito*) by those awakened after him (*anubuddhehi*); like filaments (*kesaraṃ*) surrounded by petals (*pattaparivāritaṃ viya*), like a seed pod (*kaṇṇikā*) surrounded by filaments (*kesaraparivāritā viya*), like a six-tusked elephant king (*chaddanto nāgarājā*) surrounded (*parivārito viya*) by eight thousand elephants (*aṭṭhanāgasahassa*), like a *dhataraṭṭha* swan king (*haṃsarājā*) surrounded (*parivārito viya*) by ninety thousand geese (*navutihaṃsasahassa*), like an emperor (*cakkavattirājā*) surrounded (*parivārito viya*) by an army (*senaṅga*), like Sakka (*sakko*) the king of the gods (*devarājā*) surrounded (*parivārito viya*) by a host of gods (*devagaṇa*), like Hārita (*hārito*) the Great Brahmā (*mahābrahmā*) surrounded (*parivārito viya*) by a host of Brahmās (*brahmagaṇa*), with the grace (*līlāya*) of a Buddha (*buddha*) produced (*nibbattāya*) through the power of merit (*puññabala*) accumulated (*sañcita*) for an immeasurable time (*aparimitakāla*), inconceivable (*acinteyyāya*), incomparable (*anopamāya*), like the moon (*cando*) across the sky (*gaganatalaṃ*), he was proceeding (*paṭipanno hoti*) on that road (*taṃ maggaṃ*).
Then (*atha*), thus (*evaṃ*) as the Blessed One (*bhagavantaṃ*) was going (*gacchantaṃ*) with the incomparable (*anopamāya*) grace of a Buddha (*buddhalīlāya*), and the monks (*bhikkhū ca*) with lowered eyes (*okkhittacakkhū*), tranquil senses (*santindriye*), and tranquil minds (*santamānase*) honoring (*namassamāne*) the Blessed One (*bhagavantaṃyeva*) like the full moon (*puṇṇacandaṃ viya*) standing (*ṭhitaṃ*) in the upper sky (*uparinabhe*), having seen (*disvāva*), the wanderer (*paribbājako*) surveyed (*avalokesi*) his own assembly (*attano parisaṃ*).
She (*sā hoti*) was one whose burden (*bhārabharitā*) of various requisites (*anekaparikkhāra*) such as dilapidated stools (*kājadaṇḍake*), having hung (*olambetvā*), and having grasped (*gahitā*), *ulugga, vilugga, piṭṭhaka, tidaṇḍa*, peacock fans (*morapiñcha*), earthen bowls (*mattikāpatta*), sacks (*pasibbaka*), water pots (*kuṇḍikādi*).
"So-and-so's hands (*hatthā*) are beautiful (*sobhaṇā*), so-and-so's feet (*pādā*)," etc. [They were] those with loose tongues (*mukharā*) [filled with] meaningless words (*evamādiniratthakavacanā*) and scattered speech (*vikiṇṇavācā*), unsightly (*adassanīyā*), uninspiring (*apāsādikā*).
Having seen (*disvā*) that (*taṃ*), remorse (*vippaṭisāro*) arose (*udapādi*) in him (*tassa*).
Now (*idāni*) praise (*vaṇṇo*) of the Blessed One (*bhagavato*) should be spoken (*vattabbo bhaveyya*) by him (*tena*).
Since (*yasmā*) he (*panesa*) is constantly jealous (*niccampi bhagavantaṃ usūyati*) because of the loss (*hāniyā*) of gain (*lābha*) and honor (*sakkāra*) as well as the loss (*hāniyā*) of his following (*pakkha*).
For (*hi*) so long as (*yāva*) a Buddha (*buddho*) does not arise (*nuppajjati*) in the world (*loke*), just so long (*tāva*) do gain (*lābha*) and honor (*sakkārā*) arise (*nibbattanti*); but from the arising (*buddhuppādato*) of a Buddha (*paṭṭhāya*) there is diminished gain (*parihīnalābha*) and honor (*sakkārā*); like glow-worms (*khajjopanakā*) at sunrise (*sūriyuggamane*) they undergo (*āpajjanti*) a state of being without glory (*nissirīkataṃ viya*).
Moreover, at the time (*santike*) when Upatissa (*upatissa*) and Kolita (*kolitānañca*) went forth (*pabbajitakāleyeva*) under Sañjaya (*sañjayassa*), the wanderers (*paribbājakā*) had a great assembly (*mahāparisā ahesuṃ*); but when they (*tesu*) had departed (*pakkantesu*), that (*sāpi*) assembly (*parisā*) of theirs (*tesaṃ*) was split (*bhinnā*).
Thus (*iti*), because of these two (*imehi dvīhi*) reasons (*kāraṇehi*) why (*yasmā*) this wanderer (*ayaṃ paribbājako*) is constantly jealous (*niccampi bhagavantaṃ usūyati*), therefore (*tasmā*) vomiting up (*uggiranto*) that (*taṃ*) poison (*visuggāraṃ*) of jealousy (*usūya*), he speaks (*bhāsatīti*) only dispraise (*avaṇṇameva*) of the Triple Gem (*ratanattayassa*); it should be understood (*veditabbo*).

mula_pali: 2. Atha kho bhagavā ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ rājāgārake ekarattivāsaṃ upagacchi upagañchi (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.) saddhiṃ  bhikkhusaṅghena. Suppiyopi kho paribbājako ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ rājāgārake ekarattivāsaṃ upagacchi upagañchi (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.) antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena. Tatrapi sudaṃ suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa  avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati; suppiyassa pana  paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati. Itiha te ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā viharanti.
mula_english: 2. Then the Blessed One, together with a community of monks ( *bhikkhusaṅghena*), approached and stayed for one night in the royal rest-house in Ambalaṭṭhika. Suppiya the Wanderer, together with his pupil Brahmadatta, the youth ( *māṇavena*), also approached and stayed for one night in the royal rest-house in Ambalaṭṭhika.
