Āsabhivācābhāsanaṃ appaṭivattiyavaradhammacakkappavattanassa pubbanimittaṃ. Tathā ayaṃ bhagavāpi gato, tañcassa gamanaṃ tathaṃ ahosi, avitathaṃ, tesaṃyeva visesādhigamānaṃ pubbanimittabhāvena. Tenāhu porāṇā – Evaṃ  tathā gatoti tathāgato. Atha vā yathā vipassī bhagavā…pe… yathā kassapo bhagavā, ayampi bhagavā tatheva nekkhammena kāmacchandaṃ pahāya gato , abyāpādena byāpādaṃ, ālokasaññāya thinamiddhaṃ, avikkhepena uddhaccakukkuccaṃ, dhammavavatthānena vicikicchaṃ pahāya ñāṇena avijjaṃ padāletvā, pāmojjena  aratiṃ vinodetvā, paṭhamajjhānena nīvaraṇakavāṭaṃ ugghāṭetvā, dutiyajjhānena vitakkavicāraṃ vūpasametvā, tatiyajjhānena pītiṃ virājetvā, catutthajjhānena sukhadukkhaṃ pahāya, ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattiyā rūpasaññāpaṭighasaññānānattasaññāyo samatikkamitvā, viññāṇañcāyatanasamāpattiyā ākāsānañcāyatanasaññaṃ, ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpattiyā viññāṇañcāyatanasaññaṃ, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiyā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ samatikkamitvā gato. Aniccānupassanāya niccasaññaṃ pahāya, dukkhānupassanāya sukhasaññaṃ, anattānupassanāya attasaññaṃ, nibbidānupassanāya nandiṃ, virāgānupassanāya rāgaṃ, nirodhānupassanāya samudayaṃ, paṭinissaggānupassanāya ādānaṃ, khayānupassanāya ghanasaññaṃ, vayānupassanāya āyūhanaṃ, vipariṇāmānupassanāya dhuvasaññaṃ, animittānupassanāya nimittaṃ, appaṇihitānupassanāya paṇidhiṃ, suññatānupassanāya abhinivesaṃ, adhipaññādhammavipassanāya sārādānābhinivesaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanena sammohābhinivesaṃ, ādīnavānupassanāya ālayābhinivesaṃ, paṭisaṅkhānupassanāya appaṭisaṅkhaṃ, vivaṭṭānupassanāya saṃyogābhinivesaṃ, sotāpattimaggena diṭṭhekaṭṭhe kilese bhañjitvā, sakadāgāmimaggena oḷārike kilese pahāya, anāgāmimaggena aṇusahagate kilese samugghāṭetvā, arahattamaggena sabbakilese samucchinditvā gato. Evampi tathā gatoti tathāgato. Kathaṃ tathalakkhaṇaṃ āgatoti tathāgato?Pathavīdhātuyā kakkhaḷattalakkhaṇaṃ tathaṃ avitathaṃ. Āpodhātuyā paggharaṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Tejodhātuyā uṇhattalakkhaṇaṃ. Vāyodhātuyā vitthambhanalakkhaṇaṃ. Ākāsadhātuyā asamphuṭṭhalakkhaṇaṃ. Viññāṇadhātuyā vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ. Rūpassa  ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ. Vedanāya vedayitalakkhaṇaṃ. Saññāya sañjānanalakkhaṇaṃ. Saṅkhārānaṃ abhisaṅkharaṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Viññāṇassa vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ. Vitakkassa  abhiniropanalakkhaṇaṃ. Vicārassa anumajjanalakkhaṇaṃ pītiyā pharaṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Sukhassa sātalakkhaṇaṃ. Cittekaggatāya avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ. Phassassa phusanalakkhaṇaṃ. Saddhindriyassa adhimokkhalakkhaṇaṃ. Vīriyindriyassa paggahalakkhaṇaṃ. Satindriyassa upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇaṃ. Samādhindriyassa avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ. Paññindriyassa pajānanalakkhaṇaṃ. Saddhābalassa assaddhiye akampiyalakkhaṇaṃ. Vīriyabalassa kosajje, satibalassa muṭṭhassacce. Samādhibalassa uddhacce, paññābalassa avijjāya akampiyalakkhaṇaṃ. Satisambojjhaṅgassa upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇaṃ. Dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgassa pavicayalakkhaṇaṃ. Vīriyasambojjhaṅgassa paggahalakkhaṇaṃ. Pītisambojjhaṅgassa pharaṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa vūpasamalakkhaṇaṃ. Samādhisambojjhaṅgassa avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ. Upekkhāsambojjhaṅgassa paṭisaṅkhānalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammādiṭṭhiyā dassanalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāsaṅkappassa abhiniropanalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāvācāya pariggahalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammākammantassa samuṭṭhānalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāājīvassa vodānalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāvāyāmassa  paggahalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāsatiyā upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāsamādhissa avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ. Avijjāya aññāṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Saṅkhārānaṃ cetanālakkhaṇaṃ. Viññāṇassa vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ. Nāmassa namanalakkhaṇaṃ. Rūpassa ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ. Saḷāyatanassa āyatanalakkhaṇaṃ. Phassassa phusanalakkhaṇaṃ. Vedanāya vedayitalakkhaṇaṃ. Taṇhāya hetulakkhaṇaṃ. Upādānassa gahaṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Bhavassa āyūhanalakkhaṇaṃ. Jātiyā nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ. Jarāya jīraṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Maraṇassa cutilakkhaṇaṃ. Dhātūnaṃ suññatālakkhaṇaṃ. Āyatanānaṃ āyatanalakkhaṇaṃ. Satipaṭṭhānānaṃ upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammappadhānānaṃ padahanalakkhaṇaṃ. Iddhipādānaṃ ijjhanalakkhaṇaṃ. Indriyānaṃ adhipatilakkhaṇaṃ. Balānaṃ akampiyalakkhaṇaṃ. Bojjhaṅgānaṃ niyyānalakkhaṇaṃ. Maggassa hetulakkhaṇaṃ. Saccānaṃ  tathalakkhaṇaṃ. Samathassa avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ. Vipassanāya anupassanālakkhaṇaṃ. Samathavipassanānaṃ ekarasalakkhaṇaṃ. Yuganaddhānaṃ anativattanalakkhaṇaṃ. Sīlavisuddhiyā saṃvaralakkhaṇaṃ. Cittavisuddhiyā avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ. Diṭṭhivisuddhiyā dassanalakkhaṇaṃ. Khaye ñāṇassa samucchedanalakkhaṇaṃ. Anuppāde ñāṇassa passaddhilakkhaṇaṃ. Chandassa  mūlalakkhaṇaṃ. Manasikārassa samuṭṭhāpanalakkhaṇaṃ. Phassassa samodhānalakkhaṇaṃ. Vedanāya samosaraṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Samādhissa pamukhalakkhaṇaṃ. Satiyā ādhipateyyalakkhaṇaṃ. Paññāya tatuttariyalakkhaṇaṃ. Vimuttiyā sāralakkhaṇaṃ… amatogadhassa nibbānassa pariyosānalakkhaṇaṃ tathaṃ avitathaṃ. Evaṃ tathalakkhaṇaṃ ñāṇagatiyā āgato avirajjhitvā patto anuppattoti tathāgato. Evaṃ tathalakkhaṇaṃ āgatoti tathāgato. Kathaṃ tathadhamme yāthāvato abhisambuddhoti tathāgato?  Tathadhammā nāma cattāri ariyasaccāni. Yathāha – ‘‘cattārimāni, bhikkhave, tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni. Katamāni cattāri? ‘Idaṃ dukkha’nti bhikkhave, tathametaṃ avitathametaṃ anaññathameta’’nti (saṃ. ni. 5.1090) vitthāro. Tāni ca bhagavā abhisambuddho, tasmā tathānaṃ dhammānaṃ abhisambuddhattā tathāgatoti vuccati. Abhisambuddhattho hettha gatasaddo. Api ca jarāmaraṇassa jātipaccayasambhūtasamudāgataṭṭho tatho avitatho anaññatho…pe…, saṅkhārānaṃ avijjāpaccayasambhūtasamudāgataṭṭho tatho avitatho anaññatho…pe…, tathā avijjāya saṅkhārānaṃ paccayaṭṭho, saṅkhārānaṃ viññāṇassa paccayaṭṭho…pe…, jātiyā jarāmaraṇassa paccayaṭṭho tatho avitatho anaññatho. Taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavā abhisambuddho, tasmāpi tathānaṃ dhammānaṃ abhisambuddhattā tathāgatoti vuccati. Evaṃ tathadhamme yāthāvato abhisambuddhoti tathāgato. Kathaṃ tathadassitāya tathāgato? Bhagavā yaṃ sadevake loke…pe…, sadevamanussāya pajāya aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānaṃ  sattānaṃ cakkhudvāre āpāthamāgacchantaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ nāma atthi, taṃ sabbākārato jānāti passati. Evaṃ jānatā passatā ca, tena taṃ  iṭṭhāniṭṭhādivasena vā diṭṭhasutamutaviññātesu labbhamānakapadavasena vā. ‘‘Katamaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ? Yaṃ  rūpaṃ catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ upādāya vaṇṇanibhā sanidassanaṃ sappaṭighaṃ nīlaṃ pītaka’’ntiādinā (dha. sa. 616) nayena anekehi nāmehi terasahi vārehi dvepaññāsāya nayehi vibhajjamānaṃ tathameva hoti, vitathaṃ natthi. Esa nayo sotadvārādīsupi āpāthaṃ āgacchantesu saddādīsu. Vuttañcetaṃ bhagavatā – ‘‘yaṃ bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa…pe… sadevamanussāya pajāya diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tamahaṃ jānāmi. Tamahaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, taṃ tathāgatassa viditaṃ, taṃ tathāgato na upaṭṭhāsī’’ti (a. ni. 4.24). Evaṃ tathadassitāya tathāgato. Tattha tathadassī atthe tathāgatoti padasambhavo veditabbo. Kathaṃ tathavāditāya tathāgato? Yaṃ rattiṃ bhagavā bodhimaṇḍe aparājitapallaṅke nisinno tiṇṇaṃ mārānaṃ matthakaṃ madditvā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho, yañca rattiṃ yamakasālānamantare anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyi, etthantare pañcacattālīsavassaparimāṇe kāle paṭhamabodhiyāpi majjhimabodhiyāpi pacchimabodhiyāpi yaṃ bhagavatā bhāsitaṃ – suttaṃ, geyyaṃ…pe… vedallaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ atthato ca byañjanato ca anupavajjaṃ, anūnamanadhikaṃ, sabbākāraparipuṇṇaṃ, rāgamadanimmadanaṃ, dosamohamadanimmadanaṃ. Natthi tattha vālaggamattampi avakkhalitaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ ekamuddikāya lañchitaṃ viya, ekanāḷiyā mitaṃ viya, ekatulāya tulitaṃ viya ca, tathameva hoti avitathaṃ anaññathaṃ. Tenāha – ‘‘yañca, cunda, rattiṃ tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhati, yañca rattiṃ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, yaṃ etasmiṃ antare bhāsati lapati niddisati, sabbaṃ taṃ tatheva hoti, no aññathā. Tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccatī’’ti (a. ni. 4.23). Gadattho hettha gatasaddo. Evaṃ tathavāditāya tathāgato. Api  ca āgadanaṃ āgado, vacananti attho. Tayo aviparīto āgado assāti, da-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā tathāgatoti evametasmiṃ atthe padasiddhi veditabbā. Kathaṃ tathākāritāya tathāgato? Bhagavato hi vācāya kāyo anulometi, kāyassapi vācā, tasmā yathāvādī tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī ca hoti. Evaṃbhūtassa cassa yathāvācā, kāyopi tathā gato pavattoti attho. Yathā ca kāyo, vācāpi tathā gatā pavattāti tathāgato. Tenevāha – ‘‘yathāvādī, bhikkhave, tathāgato tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī . Iti yathāvādī tathākārī yathākārī tathāvādī. Tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccatī’’ti (a. ni. 4.23). Evaṃ tathākāritāya tathāgato. Kathaṃ abhibhavanaṭṭhena tathāgato? Upari bhavaggaṃ heṭṭhā avīciṃ pariyantaṃ katvā tiriyaṃ aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu sabbasatte abhibhavati sīlenapi samādhināpi paññāyapi vimuttiyāpi, vimuttiñāṇadassanenapi na tassa tulā vā pamāṇaṃ vā atthi; atulo appameyyo anuttaro rājātirājā devadevo sakkānaṃ atisakko brahmānaṃ atibrahmā. Tenāha – ‘‘sadevake, bhikkhave, loke…pe… sadevamanussāya pajāya tathāgato abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī, tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccatī’’ti. Tatrevaṃ padasiddhi veditabbā. Agado viya agado. Ko panesa? Desanāvilāsamayo ceva puññussayo ca. Tena hesa mahānubhāvo bhisakko dibbāgadena sappe viya sabbaparappavādino sadevakañca lokaṃ abhibhavati. Iti sabbālokābhibhavane tatho aviparīto desanāvilāsamayo ceva puññussayo ca agado assāti. Da-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā tathāgatoti veditabbo. Evaṃ abhibhavanaṭṭhena tathāgato. Api ca tathāya gatotipi tathāgato, tathaṃ gatotipi tathāgato. Gatoti avagato, atīto patto paṭipannoti attho. Tattha  sakalalokaṃ tīraṇapariññāya tathāya gato avagatoti tathāgato. Lokasamudayaṃ pahānapariññāya tathāya gato atītoti tathāgato. Lokanirodhaṃ sacchikiriyāya tathāya gato pattoti tathāgato. Lokanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ tathaṃ gato paṭipannoti tathāgato. Tena  vuttaṃ bhagavatā – Tassapi  evaṃ attho veditabbo. Idampi ca tathāgatassa tathāgatabhāvadīpane mukhamattameva. Sabbākārena pana tathāgatova tathāgatassa tathāgatabhāvaṃ vaṇṇeyya. Katamañca taṃ bhikkhaveti yena appamattakena oramattakena sīlamattakena puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya, taṃ katamanti pucchati? Tattha pucchā nāma adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā, diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchā, vimaticchedanā pucchā, anumatipucchā, kathetukamyatā pucchāti pañcavidhā hoti. Tattha katamā adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā? Pakatiyā lakkhaṇaṃ aññātaṃ hoti, adiṭṭhaṃ atulitaṃ atīritaṃ avibhūtaṃ avibhāvitaṃ, tassa ñāṇāya dassanāya tulanāya tīraṇāya vibhāvanāya pañhaṃ pucchati, ayaṃ adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā. Katamā diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchā? Pakatiyā lakkhaṇaṃ ñātaṃ hoti, diṭṭhaṃ tulitaṃ tīritaṃ vibhūtaṃ vibhāvitaṃ, tassa aññehi paṇḍitehi saddhiṃ saṃsandanatthāya pañhaṃ pucchati, ayaṃ diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchā. Katamā vimaticchedanā pucchā? Pakatiyā saṃsayapakkhando hoti, vimatipakkhando, dveḷhakajāto, ‘‘evaṃ nu kho, na nu kho, kinnu kho, kathaṃ nu kho’’ti. So vimaticchedanatthāya pañhaṃ pucchati. Ayaṃ vimaticchedanā pucchā. Katamā anumatipucchā? Bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ anumatiyā pañhaṃ pucchati – ‘‘taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā’’ti. Aniccaṃ, bhante. Yaṃ panāniccaṃ , dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vāti? Dukkhaṃ bhanteti (mahāva. 21) sabbaṃ vattabbaṃ, ayaṃ anumatipucchā. Katamā kathetukamyatā pucchā? Bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ kathetukamyatāya pañhaṃ pucchati. Cattārome, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhānā. Katame cattāro?…Pe… aṭṭhime bhikkhave maggaṅgā. Katame aṭṭhāti, ayaṃ kathetukamyatā pucchā. Iti imāsu pañcasu pucchāsu adiṭṭhassa tāva kassaci dhammassa abhāvato tathāgatassa adiṭṭhajotanā  pucchā natthi. ‘‘Idaṃ nāma aññehi paṇḍitehi samaṇabrāhmaṇehi saddhiṃ saṃsanditvā desessāmī’’ti samannāhārasseva anuppajjanato diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchāpi natthi. Yasmā pana buddhānaṃ ekadhammepi āsappanā parisappanā natthi, bodhimaṇḍeyeva sabbā kaṅkhā chinnā; tasmā vimaticchedanā pucchāpi natthiyeva. Avasesā pana dve pucchā buddhānaṃ atthi, tāsu ayaṃ kathetukamyatā pucchā nāma.
commentary_english:
7. "Appamattakaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhaveti": What is the connection? This *sutta* is bound by two terms: praise (*vaṇṇa*) and dispraise (*avaṇṇa*).

There, dispraise is refuted by pointing out: “For such and such a reason this is false (*abhūtaṃ*), this is untrue (*ataccha*).” etc., just as fire is extinguished by submerging it in water.

And praise is confirmed by acknowledging fact as fact thus: “For such and such a reason this is a fact (*bhūtaṃ*).”

Praise is of two kinds: that spoken by Brahmadatta and that spoken by the company of *bhikkhus* beginning with "Wonderful, friend!" (*acchariyaṃ āvuso*), etc.

Among them, the Master will show the sequel to the praise spoken by the company of *bhikkhus* later in the *sutta*, in the section on the elucidation of emptiness (*suññatā*).

Here he begins the teaching by showing the sequel to the praise spoken by Brahmadatta: “*Appamattakaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave*.”

There, "*appamattaka*" is a name for insignificance (*paritta*).

"*Oramattaka*" is a synonym of that.

"*Mattā*" means measure (*pamāṇaṃ*).

"*Appaṃ mattā etassa*" means insignificant (*appamattakaṃ*).

"*Oraṃ mattā etassa*" means inferior (*oramattakaṃ*).

Virtue (*sīla*) itself is just virtue (*sīlamattakaṃ*).

This is what is meant: ‘*Appamattakaṃ kho, panetaṃ bhikkhave, oramattakaṃ sīlamattakaṃ*’ means that a worldling might speak even after making an effort, saying “I will speak praise of the *Tathāgata*.”

Here it might be asked: Surely virtue (*sīla*) is the supreme adornment (*aggavibhūsanaṃ*) of a *yogin*? As the ancients have said: And the Exalted One himself has extolled virtue in many hundreds of *suttas*.

For example: “If, *bhikkhus*, a *bhikkhu* should wish: ‘May I be dear and agreeable to my companions in the holy life (*sabrahmacārī*), revered and esteemed,’ he should be perfect in fulfilling the rules of conduct (*sīla*)” etc. (Ma. Ni. 1. 65).

“As, *bhikkhus*, whatever seed groups (*bījagāma*) and vegetable groups (*bhūtagāma*) come to growth (*vuḍḍhiṃ*), increase (*virūḷhiṃ*) and maturity (*vepullaṃ*), all do so by being dependent on the earth (*pathavī*); so these seed groups and vegetable groups come to growth, increase and maturity.

Even so, *bhikkhus*, a *bhikkhu*, by relying on virtue (*sīla*), by being established in virtue, developing the seven factors of enlightenment (*sattabojjhaṅga*), cultivating the seven factors of enlightenment, comes to growth, increase and maturity in the Dhamma” (Saṃ. Ni. 5. 150).

Thus also other many *suttas* should be seen.

And so too in many other *suttas* virtue is extolled.

Then why does he say “insignificant (*appamattaka*)” in this instance? He does so by placing the superior qualities above.

For virtue does not reach the level of the excellence of concentration (*samādhi*) and concentration does not reach the level of the excellence of wisdom (*paññā*). Therefore, in comparison with the higher qualities, the inferior ones are called “insignificant (*oramattakaṃ*).”

How is it that virtue does not reach the level of the excellence of concentration? The Exalted One, after he was fully enlightened, in the seventh year, at the city gate of Sāvatthī, at the foot of the Kaṇḍamba tree, in a jewelled pavilion twelve *yojanas* wide, while sitting on a jewelled divan one *yojana* wide, under a divine white parasol three *yojanas* wide, before an assembly of people extending for twelve *yojanas* in all directions, showing his acceptance of the challenge posed by the sectarians and quelling their forces, performed the twin miracle: “From the upper part of his body a mass of fire issued forth, and from the lower part a stream of water… from each hair-pore a mass of fire issued forth, and from each hair-pore a stream of water, of six colors,” and so on.

From his body of golden color, rays of golden color issued forth, continuing on to the summit of existence (*bhavagga*), as if it were a time of adorning the entire ten-thousandfold world sphere. The remaining colored rays, issuing from his body in turn according to color, came forth so that they appeared to come forth simultaneously, at a single moment.

And there is no occurrence of two acts of consciousness (*citta*) at a single moment.

But in the case of the Buddhas, by reason of the brevity of their stay in the *bhavaṅga* and through their fivefold mastery, the differently colored rays appeared to come forth at a single moment.

But in reality the adverting, preparation, and resolution for each colored ray is done separately.

The Exalted One attains the blue *kasiṇa* absorption in order to produce the blue rays, the yellow *kasiṇa* in order to produce the yellow rays, the red and white *kasiṇas* in order to produce the red and white rays, the fire *kasiṇa* in order to produce the mass of fire, and the water *kasiṇa* in order to produce the stream of water.

The Master paces up and down, while projected images of himself stand or sit or lie down and so on; all may he explained at length.

In all this, there is not even one thing that was accomplished by virtue. All was accomplished by concentration.

Thus virtue does not reach the level of the excellence of concentration.

Moreover, what the Exalted One, after fulfilling the perfections (*pārami*) for four incalculable periods of a hundred thousand *kappas*, at the age of twenty-nine, departing from the palace that was the glorious abode of a wheel-turning monarch (*cakkavatti*), going forth on the bank of the Anoma River, practicing striving (*padhānayoga*) for six years, on the Visakha full-moon day, after partaking of milk-rice (*madhupāyāsa*) mixed with divine nourishment that had been offered by Sujātā in the village of Uruvela, in the evening, entering the *bodhi-maṇḍa* from the south-east, circumambulating the king of *assattha* trees three times, standing on the north-eastern side, after spreading out a grass mat, after crossing his legs in the three-jointed lotus posture, having made goodwill (*mettā*) the foremost object of his attention, resolving on effort (*vīriya*), having made the trunk of the *bodhi* tree fifty *hatthas* high stand behind him like a silver column placed on a golden seat on a divan fourteen *hatthas* high, being sheltered above by the branch of the *bodhi* tree like a jeweled parasol, while the golden robes and the coral-like shoots of the *bodhi* tree fell down, as the sun was setting, dispelling the forces of Māra, in the first watch of the night recollecting his former abodes (*pubbenivāsa*), in the middle watch purifying the divine eye (*dibbacakkhu*), at dawn reflecting on the causal relations in the way that is habitual for all Buddhas, after developing the fourth *jhāna* based on mindfulness of breathing, after using that as his footing, after increasing insight (*vipassanā*), by means of the fourth path attained through the order of the paths, destroying all defilements (*kilesa*) and realizing all the qualities of a Buddha – this was his function of wisdom (*paññā*).

Thus concentration does not reach to the excellence of wisdom.

There, just as the water in the hand does not reach the water in a bowl, the water in a bowl does not reach the water in a jar, the water in a jar does not reach the water in a trough, the water in a trough does not reach the water in a pot, the water in a pot does not reach the water in a large pot, the water in a large pot does not reach the water in a cistern, the water in a cistern does not reach the water in a hollow, the water in a hollow does not reach the water in a small stream, the water in a small stream does not reach the water in the five great rivers, the water in the five great rivers does not reach the water in the great sea surrounding the *cakkavāḷa*, the water in the great sea surrounding the *cakkavāḷa* does not reach the water in the great sea at the foot of Mount Sineru.
Having placed water in a bowl, a small amount of water in the hand…and so on… having placed water in the ocean at the foot of Mount Meru, a small amount of water in the great *cakravāḷa* ocean.

Thus, taking much water from above, the water below becomes little.

Just so, taking each higher quality above, virtue ( *sīla*) below should be understood as "trifling" and "insignificant."

Therefore, he said: "Indeed, monks, this trifling, insignificant, mere virtue."

Regarding "by whom [is known] the worldling (*puthujjana*)": Here, there, whoever does not have acquisition, questioning, hearing, retention, and reflection on the aggregates (*khandha*), elements (*dhātu*), sense-bases (*āyatana*), etc., this one is a blind worldling (*andha-puthujjana*).

Whoever has those things, he is a virtuous worldling (*kalyāṇa-puthujjana*).

This one is twofold – he is a worldling (*puthujjana*) because of causes such as the generation, etc., of many kinds of defilements (*kilesa*), etc.

As he said: "They generate a multitude of defilements, hence they are worldlings (*puthujjana*). They have not destroyed the multiple forms of personality view (*sakkāya-diṭṭhi*), hence they are worldlings (*puthujjana*). They look up to a multitude of teachers (*satthar*), hence they are worldlings (*puthujjana*). They have not emerged from the multitude of destinations, hence they are worldlings (*puthujjana*). They form multiple kamma-formations (*abhisaṅkhāra*), hence they are worldlings (*puthujjana*). They are swept away by a multitude of floods (*ogha*), afflicted by a multitude of afflictions (*santāpa*), consumed by a multitude of fevers (*pariḷāha*)—hence they are worldlings (*puthujjana*). They are lustful and greedy for the five strands of sense pleasure (*kāmaguṇa*): attached, desiring, tied, infatuated, deep-seated, clinging, attached, bound up—hence they are worldlings (*puthujjana*). They are covered, closed, enveloped, hidden, concealed, rejected by the five hindrances (*nīvaraṇa*)—hence they are worldlings (*puthujjana*)."

One who is included among the multitude of people who live according to an inferior doctrine (*nīcadhammasamācāra*) and are averse to the doctrine of the *ariyas* ( *ariya-dhamma*), is called a worldling (*puthujjana*). And a person distinct or remote from the *ariyas* endowed with such qualities as virtue (*sīla*), learning (*suta*), etc., is called a worldling (*puthujjana*).

The Exalted One is called the *Tathāgata* for eight reasons.

The *Tathāgata* is so called because he has "thus come" (*tathā āgata*), because he has "thus gone" (*tathā gata*), because he has come to the real characteristic (*tathā-lakkhaṇaṃ āgata*), because he has awakened to real dhammas in accordance with actuality (*tathā-dhamme yāthāvato abhisambuddha*), because he is a seer of the real (*tathā-dassitāya*), because he is a speaker of the real (*tathā-vāditāya*), because he acts in accordance with his teaching (*tathā-kāritāya*), and in the sense of surpassing (*abhibhavanaṭṭhena*).

Why is the Exalted One called the *Tathāgata* because he has "thus come"? Because the previous fully awakened Buddhas (*sammāsambuddha*) came, engaged in exertion for the welfare of the whole world (*sabba-loka-hitāya*), came—that is, as the Exalted Vipassī, the Exalted Sikhī, the Exalted Vessabhū, the Exalted Kakusandha, the Exalted Koṇāgamana, and the Exalted Kassapa .

What does this mean? Our Exalted One has come through the very same aspiration (*abhinīhāra*) that these Exalted Ones came through.

Or just as the Exalted Vipassī…pe… the Exalted Kassapa came after they had fulfilled the perfection of giving (*dāna-pāramī*) after fulfilling the perfections (*pāramī*) of virtue (*sīla*), renunciation (*nekkhamma*), wisdom (*paññā*), energy (*vīriya*), patience (*khanti*), truthfulness (*sacca*), determination (*adhiṭṭhāna*), loving kindness (*mettā*), and equanimity (*upekkhā*), came after they had fulfilled these ten perfections (*dasa pāramiyo*), ten intermediate perfections (*dasa upapāramiyo*), and ten ultimate perfections (*dasa paramatthapāramiyo*), making the full thirty perfections (*samatiṃsa pāramiyo*); made the five great relinquishments (*pañca mahāpariccāge*)—i.e., the relinquishing of limbs (*aṅga-pariccāga*), eyes (*nayana*), wealth (*dhana*), kingdom (*rajja*), and children and wife (*putta-dāra-pariccāga*); fulfilled the preliminary effort (*pubba-yoga*), the preliminary conduct (*pubba-cariya*), the preaching of the *Dhamma* (*dhamma-akkhāna*), conduct conducive to understanding, etc.; attained the limit of the practice of wisdom (*buddhi-cariyāya koṭiṃ patvā āgato*); just so has our Exalted One come.

Or else, just as the Exalted Vipassī … Kassapa came by developing and cultivating the four foundations of mindfulness (*satipaṭṭhāna*), the four right endeavors (*sammappadhāna*), the four bases of spiritual success (*iddhipāda*), the five faculties (*indriya*), the five powers (*bala*), the seven factors of enlightenment (*bojjhaṅga*), and the Noble Eightfold Path (*ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ*)—exactly thus has our Exalted One come.

Thus he is the *Tathāgata* because he has “thus come.”

Thus he is the *Tathāgata* because he has “thus come.”

Why is he called the *Tathāgata* because he has "thus gone"? Because as soon as he was born, the Exalted Vipassī went…pe… Kassapa went as soon as they were born.

And how did that Exalted One go? As soon as he was born he stood with his feet planted evenly on the ground, and then, facing north, went forward with a stride of seven steps.

As it is said: "As soon as the *bodhisattva* was born, Ānanda, he stood with his feet planted evenly on the ground; then, while a white parasol was held over him, facing north, he went forward with a stride of seven steps. Having surveyed all the directions, he then uttered the roar of the Leader of the Herd: 'I am the foremost in the world. I am pre-eminent in the world. I am supreme in the world. This is my last birth. There is now no renewal of existence.'" (Dī.

And his way of going was real? Not unreal, for it was a foretoken of the achievements of distinction.

When he stood with his feet planted evenly on the ground,

that was the foretoken of his obtaining the four bases of spiritual success (*iddhipāda*).

When he walked facing north (*uttarābhimukhabhāvo*), that was the foretoken of his supremacy in all the world.

His stride of seven steps foretokened his obtaining the gems of the seven factors of enlightenment (*bojjhaṅga*).

The golden-staffed chowries that appeared foretokened his defeat of all the sectarian teachers (*titthiya*).

The white parasol foretokened his obtaining the stainless white parasol of the supreme deliverance of arahatship.

When he stood surveying all the directions after completing the seventh step, that foretokened his obtaining the unobstructed knowledge of omniscience.

And his uttering the roar of the Leader of the Herd was the foretoken of his setting in motion the supreme, irreversible Wheel of the *Dhamma*.

Just as the previous Exalted Ones went thus, exactly thus did the present Exalted One go. And his way of going was real, not unreal, for it foretokened the above achievements of spiritual distinction.

Therefore, the ancients said: Thus he is the *Tathāgata* because he has “thus gone.”

Or alternatively, as the Exalted Vipassī … the Exalted Kassapa went, exactly thus did the present Exalted One go. Why is he called the *Tathāgata* in the sense of vanquishing or surpassing? From the peak of existence (*bhava-agga*) downwards, and from the *Avīci* hell upwards, throughout the innumerable world systems (*lokadhātu*), the *Tathāgata* surpasses all beings in virtue (*śīla*), concentration (*samādhi*), wisdom (*prajñā*), and emancipation (*vimutti*), and knowledge-and-vision of emancipation (*vimutti-ñāṇa-dassana*). There is none his equal or measure. He is unequalled (*atula*), immeasurable (*appameyya*), incomparable (*anuttara*)—the king of kings (*rājātirājā*), the god of gods (*devadeva*), the *Śakka* above all *Śakkas*, the *Brahmā* above all *Brahmās*.

Thus it is said: “In this world, *bhikkhus*, together with its gods, etc., in this generation with its rulers and its men, the *Tathāgata* is the vanquisher (*abhibhū*), the unvanquished (*anabhibhūto*), the universal seer (*aññadatthudaso*), the wielder of power (*vasavattī*). Therefore he is called the *Tathāgata*.”

Here the word-derivation (*padasiddhi*) should be understood as follows.

Like a medicine (*agada*).

Who is this? His elegance of teaching (*desanāvilāsamayo*) and his accumulation of merit (*puññussayo*).

For by means of these, he vanquishes all the rival teachers as well as this world together with its gods in the same way that a powerful physician (*bhisakko*) vanquishes snakes with a divine medicine (*dibbāgadena*).

Thus his medicine (*agado*) for vanquishing all the world is his real, undistorted elegance of teaching (*desanāvilāsamayo*) and his accumulations of merit (*puññussayo*).

Changing the letter *da* to a *ta*, the derivation of the word “*Tathāgata*” may be understood thus.

Thus he is the *Tathāgata* in the sense of vanquishing (*abhibhavanaṭṭhena*).

Furthermore, he is the *Tathāgata* because he has “gone through reality” (*tathāya gato*), and because he has “really gone” (*tathaṃ gato*).

Here “gone” (*gato*) has the meanings of undergone (*avagato*), gone beyond (*atīto*), attained (*patto*), and practiced (*paṭipanno*).

Thus he is the *Tathāgata* because he has gone through—i.e., undergone (*avagato*)—reality by fully understanding the entire world (*sakalaloka*) through the scrutinization (*tīraṇapariññāya*).

He is the *Tathāgata* because he has gone through—i.e., gone beyond (*atīto*)—reality by fully understanding the world through the abandonment of its origin (*lokasamudayaṃ pahānapariññāya*).

He is the *Tathāgata* because he has gone through—i.e., attained (*patto*)—reality by realizing the cessation of the world (*lokanirodhaṃ sacchikiriyāya*).

And he is the *Tathāgata* because he has really gone along—i.e., practiced (*paṭipanno*)—the way leading to the cessation of the world (*lokanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ tathaṃ gato*).

Thus it was said by the Exalted One (*bhagavatā*) - Thus the meaning should be understood.

But this is the mere introduction (*mukhamattaṃ*) to the explanation of the nature of a *Tathāgata* (*tathāgatabhāva-dīpane*).

For only a *Tathāgata* himself can explain the nature of a *Tathāgata* (*tathāgatabhāvaṃ*) in its completeness (*sabbākārena*).

What, *bhikkhus*, is that by which an ordinary person (*puthujjana*) speaking the praise (*vaṇṇaṃ*) of the *Tathāgata* might speak, asking, "What is that?". Therein, what is a question (*pucchā*)? A question of illuminating the unseen (*adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā*), a question of comparing what has been seen (*diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchā*), a question of cutting off doubt (*vimaticchedanā pucchā*), a question of consent (*anumatipucchā*), a question of wanting to speak (*kathetukamyatā pucchā*)—it is fivefold (*pañcavidhā hoti*).

Therein, what is a question of illuminating the unseen (*adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā*)? By nature (*pakatiyā*) the characteristic (*lakkhaṇaṃ*) is unknown (*aññātaṃ hoti*), unseen (*adiṭṭhaṃ*), unweighed (*atulitaṃ*), uninvestigated (*atīritaṃ*), undeveloped (*avibhūtaṃ*), unmanifested (*avibhāvitaṃ*). He asks a question (*pañhaṃ pucchati*) for the knowledge (*ñāṇāya*), seeing (*dassanāya*), weighing (*tulanāya*), investigating (*tīraṇāya*), and manifestation (*vibhāvanāya*) of it. This is a question of illuminating the unseen (*adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā*).

What is a question of comparing what has been seen (*diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchā*)? By nature (*pakatiyā*) the characteristic (*lakkhaṇaṃ*) is known (*ñātaṃ hoti*), seen (*diṭṭhaṃ*), weighed (*tulitaṃ*), investigated (*tīritaṃ*), developed (*vibhūtaṃ*), and manifested (*vibhāvitaṃ*). He asks a question (*pañhaṃ pucchati*) for the purpose of comparing it with other learned men (*paṇḍitehi saddhiṃ saṃsandanatthāya*). This is a question of comparing what has been seen (*diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchā*).

What is a question of cutting off doubt (*vimaticchedanā pucchā*)? By nature (*pakatiyā*) there is a tendency to doubt (*saṃsayapakkhando hoti*), a tendency to uncertainty (*vimatipakkhando*), being of two minds (*dveḷhakajāto*): "Is it thus (*evaṃ nu kho*), or is it not thus (*na nu kho*), what is it (*kinnu kho*), how is it (*kathaṃ nu kho*)?".

He asks a question (*pañhaṃ pucchati*) for the purpose of cutting off doubt (*vimaticchedanatthāya*).

This is a question of cutting off doubt (*vimaticchedanā pucchā*).

What is a question of consent (*anumatipucchā*)? The Exalted One (*bhagavā*) asks the *bhikkhus* a question out of consent (*anumatiyā pañhaṃ pucchati*) – "What do you think (*taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave*), is form (*rūpaṃ*) permanent (*niccaṃ*) or impermanent (*aniccaṃ vā*)"?

Impermanent (*aniccaṃ*), venerable sir (*bhante*).

Is that which is impermanent (*yaṃ panāniccaṃ*), suffering (*dukkhaṃ*) or happiness (*sukhaṃ vā*)? Suffering (*dukkhaṃ*), venerable sir (*bhante*).

Everything should be spoken (*sabbaṃ vattabbaṃ*), this is a question of consent (*ayaṃ anumatipucchā*).

What is a question of wanting to speak (*kathetukamyatā pucchā*)? The Exalted One (*bhagavā*) asks the *bhikkhus* a question out of wanting to speak (*kathetukamyatāya pañhaṃ pucchati*).

There are these four foundations of mindfulness (*cattārome, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhānā*).

What are the four (*katame cattāro*)? ... These are the eight constituents of the path (*aṭṭhime bhikkhave maggaṅgā*).

What are the eight (*katame aṭṭha*)? This is a question of wanting to speak (*ayaṃ kathetukamyatā pucchā*).

Thus, in these five questions, since there is no unseen quality (*adiṭṭhassa dhammassa*) of any kind, therefore there is no question of illuminating the unseen (*adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā*) for the *Tathāgata*.

Since the thought does not even arise (*samannāhārasseva anuppajjanato*), “I will compare it (*saṃsanditvā desessāmi*) with other learned ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* (*aññehi paṇḍitehi samaṇabrāhmaṇehi saddhiṃ*)," therefore there is also no question of comparing what has been seen (*diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchāpi natthi*).

Since there is no wavering (*āsappanā parisappanā natthi*) in even one quality for the Buddhas (*buddhānaṃ ekadhammepi*), all doubts are cut off (*sabbā kaṅkhā chinnā*) at the *Bodhi* tree (*bodhimaṇḍeyeva*); therefore there is certainly no question of cutting off doubt (*vimaticchedanā pucchāpi natthiyeva*).

But the remaining two questions (*avasesā pana dve pucchā*) exist for the Buddhas (*buddhānaṃ atthi*), among those this is called a question of wanting to speak (*ayaṃ kathetukamyatā pucchā nāma*).

mula_pali: 8. ‘‘‘Pāṇātipātaṃ  pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo nihitadaṇḍo, nihitasattho, lajjī, dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharatī’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya. ‘‘‘Adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharatī’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya. ‘‘‘Abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya brahmacārī samaṇo gotamo ārācārī anācārī (ka.) virato paṭivirato (katthaci) methunā gāmadhammā’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english:
8. “'Having abandoned the destruction of life (*prāṇātipāta*), the *śramaṇa* Gotama refrains from the destruction of life (*prāṇātipāta*). He has laid aside the rod (*daṇḍa*) and the sword (*śastra*), and dwells conscientious (*lajjī*), full of kindness (*dayāpanno*), compassionate for the welfare of all living beings (*sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī*).' It is in this way, *bhikkhus*, that the worldling (*pṛthagjana*) would speak when speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*.
“'Having abandoned taking what is not given (*adinnādāna*), the *śramaṇa* Gotama dwells refraining from taking what is not given (*adinnādāna*), living purely, accepting what is given, awaiting what is given, without stealing.' It is in this way, *bhikkhus*, that the worldling (*pṛthagjana*) would speak when speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*.
“'Having abandoned unchaste living (*abrahmacarya*), the *brahmacārī śramaṇa* Gotama lives a pure life (*brahmacārī*), refraining and abstaining from sexual acts, from vulgar practices' It is in this way, *bhikkhus*, that the worldling (*pṛthagjana*) would speak when speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*.
commentary_pali: 8. Idāni taṃ kathetukamyatāya pucchāya pucchitamatthaṃ kathetuṃ ‘‘pāṇātipātaṃ pahāyā’’tiādimāha. Tattha pāṇassa atipāto pāṇātipāto, pāṇavadho, pāṇaghātoti vuttaṃ hoti. Pāṇoti cettha vohārato satto, paramatthato jīvitindriyaṃ, tasmiṃ pana pāṇe pāṇasaññino jīvitindriyupacchedakaupakkamasamuṭṭhāpikā kāyavacīdvārānaṃ aññataradvārappavattā vadhakacetanā pāṇātipāto. So guṇavirahitesu tiracchānagatādīsu pāṇesu khuddake pāṇe appasāvajjo, mahāsarīre mahāsāvajjo, kasmā? Payogamahantatāya. Payogasamattepi vatthumahantatāya. Guṇavantesu manussādīsu appaguṇe pāṇe appasāvajjo, mahāguṇe mahāsāvajjo. Sarīraguṇānaṃ pana samabhāve sati kilesānaṃ upakkamānañca mudutāya appasāvajjo, tibbatāya mahāsāvajjoti veditabbo. Tassa  pañca sambhārā honti – pāṇo, pāṇasaññitā, vadhakacittaṃ, upakkamo, tena maraṇanti . Cha payogā – sāhatthiko, āṇattiko, nissaggiyo, thāvaro, vijjāmayo, iddhimayoti. Imasmiṃ panatthe vitthāriyamāne ativiya papañco hoti, tasmā taṃ na vitthārayāma, aññañca evarūpaṃ. Atthikehi pana samantapāsādikaṃ vinayaṭṭhakathaṃ oloketvā gahetabbaṃ. Pahāyāti imaṃ pāṇātipātacetanāsaṅkhātaṃ dussīlyaṃ pajahitvā. Paṭiviratoti pahīnakālato paṭṭhāya tato dussīlyato orato viratova. Natthi tassa vītikkamissāmīti cakkhusotaviññeyyā dhammā pageva kāyikāti imināva nayena aññesupi evarūpesu padesu attho veditabbo. Samaṇoti bhagavā samitapāpatāya laddhavohāro. Gotamoti gottavasena. Na kevalañca bhagavāyeva  pāṇātipātā paṭivirato, bhikkhusaṅghopi paṭivirato, desanā pana ādito paṭṭhāya evaṃ āgatā, atthaṃ pana dīpentena bhikkhusaṅghavasenāpi dīpetuṃ vaṭṭati. Nihitadaṇḍo nihitasatthoti parūpaghātatthāya daṇḍaṃ vā satthaṃ vā ādāya avattanato nikkhittadaṇḍo ceva nikkhittasattho cāti attho. Ettha ca ṭhapetvā daṇḍaṃ sabbampi avasesaṃ upakaraṇaṃ sattānaṃ viheṭhanabhāvato satthanti veditabbaṃ. Yaṃ pana bhikkhū kattaradaṇḍaṃ vā dantakaṭṭhaṃ vā vāsiṃ pipphalikaṃ vā gahetvā vicaranti, na taṃ parūpaghātatthāya. Tasmā nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho tveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati. Lajjīti pāpajigucchanalakkhaṇāya lajjāya samannāgato. Dayāpannoti dayaṃ mettacittataṃ āpanno. Sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampīti; sabbe pāṇabhūte hitena anukampako. Tāya dayāpannatāya sabbesaṃ pāṇabhūtānaṃ hitacittakoti attho. Viharatīti iriyati yapeti yāpeti pāleti . Iti vā hi, bhikkhaveti evaṃ vā bhikkhave. Vā saddo upari ‘‘adinnādānaṃ  pahāyā’’tiādīni apekkhitvā vikappattho vutto, evaṃ sabbattha purimaṃ vā pacchimaṃ vā apekkhitvā vikappabhāvo veditabbo. Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepo – bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno evaṃ vadeyya – ‘‘samaṇo gotamo pāṇaṃ na hanati, na ghāteti, na tattha samanuñño hoti, virato imasmā dussīlyā; aho, vata re buddhaguṇā mahantā’’ti, iti mahantaṃ ussāhaṃ katvā vaṇṇaṃ vattukāmopi appamattakaṃ oramattakaṃ ācārasīlamattakameva vakkhati. Upari asādhāraṇabhāvaṃ nissāya vaṇṇaṃ vattuṃ na sakkhissati. Na kevalañca puthujjanova sotāpannasakadāgāmianāgāmiarahantopi paccekabuddhāpi na sakkontiyeva; tathāgatoyeva pana sakkoti, taṃ vo upari vakkhāmīti, ayamettha sādhippāyā atthavaṇṇanā. Ito paraṃ pana apubbapadameva vaṇṇayissāma. Adinnādānaṃ pahāyāti ettha adinnassa ādānaṃ adinnādānaṃ, parasaṃharaṇaṃ, theyyaṃ, corikāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha adinnanti parapariggahitaṃ, yattha paro yathākāmakāritaṃ āpajjanto adaṇḍāraho anupavajjo ca hoti. Tasmiṃ parapariggahite parapariggahitasaññino, tadādāyakaupakkamasamuṭṭhāpikā theyyacetanā adinnādānaṃ. Taṃ hīne parasantake appasāvajjaṃ, paṇīte mahāsāvajjaṃ, kasmā? Vatthupaṇītatāya. Vatthusamatte sati guṇādhikānaṃ santake vatthusmiṃ mahāsāvajjaṃ . Taṃ taṃ guṇādhikaṃ upādāya tato tato hīnaguṇassa santake vatthusmiṃ appasāvajjaṃ. Tassa pañca sambhārā honti – parapariggahitaṃ, parapariggahitasaññitā, theyyacittaṃ, upakkamo, tena haraṇanti. Cha payogā – sāhatthikādayova. Te ca kho yathānurūpaṃ theyyāvahāro, pasayhāvahāro, paṭicchannāvahāro, parikappāvahāro, kusāvahāroti imesaṃ avahārānaṃ vasena pavattā, ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthāro pana samantapāsādikāyaṃ vutto. Dinnameva  ādiyatīti dinnādāyī. Cittenapi dinnameva paṭikaṅkhatīti dinnapāṭikaṅkhī. Thenetīti theno. Na thenena athenena. Athenattāyeva sucibhūtena. Attanāti attabhāvena. Athenaṃ sucibhūtaṃ attānaṃ katvā viharatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Sesaṃ paṭhamasikkhāpade vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Yathā ca idha, evaṃ sabbattha. Abrahmacariyanti aseṭṭhacariyaṃ. Brahmaṃ seṭṭhaṃ ācāraṃ caratīti brahmacārī. Ārācārīti abrahmacariyato dūracārī. Methunāti rāgapariyuṭṭhānavasena sadisattā methunakāti laddhavohārehi paṭisevitabbato methunāti saṅkhyaṃ gatā asaddhammā. Gāmadhammāti gāmavāsīnaṃ dhammā.
commentary_english:
8. Now, desiring to explain that which was asked in the question, [the text] begins with "Having abandoned killing living beings".

There, *pāṇātipāta* is the transgression against living beings, *pāṇavadha* is the killing of living beings, and *pāṇaghāta* is the destruction of living beings.

Here, the word *pāṇa* conventionally signifies a being ( *satta*), but in the ultimate sense ( *paramattha*), it is the life-faculty ( *jīvitindriya*). "Killing living beings" ( *pāṇātipāta*) is the volition ( *cetanā*) of killing in one who perceives a living being as such, which occurs through one of the doors of body or speech, and initiates the act of cutting off that living being’s life-faculty.

In the case of beings devoid of moral qualities such as animals, the act of killing is less blameworthy ( *appasāvajjo*) when the being is small ( *khuddake*) in size, and more blameworthy ( *mahāsāvajjo*) when the body is large ( *mahāsarīre*). Why? Because of the magnitude of the effort ( *payogamahantatāya*).

And when the effort ( *payoga*) involved is equal, it depends on the magnitude of the object ( *vatthu*).

In the case of beings endowed with moral qualities such as humans, the act of killing is less blameworthy ( *appasāvajjo*) when the being has few moral qualities ( *appaguṇe*), and more blameworthy ( *mahāsāvajjo*) when the being has many moral qualities ( *mahāguṇe*).

When the size of the body and moral qualities are equal, however, it should be understood that it is less blameworthy ( *appasāvajjo*) when the defilements ( *kilesānaṃ*) and activity ( *upakkamānañca*) are mild ( *mudutāya*), and more blameworthy ( *mahāsāvajjoti* ) when they are strong ( *tibbatāya*).

There are five constituents for this: a living being ( *pāṇo*), awareness that it is a living being ( *pāṇasaññitā*), the mind to kill ( *vadhakacittaṃ*), activity ( *upakkamo*), and the death thereby ( *tena maraṇaṃ*).

There are six means: one’s own person ( *sāhatthiko*), command ( *āṇattiko*), a missile ( *nissaggiyo*), a fixed contrivance ( *thāvaro*), a magical spell ( *vijjāmayo*), supernormal power ( *iddhimayo*).

When this meaning is expanded, it becomes excessively complex ( *papañco*). Therefore, we shall not expand upon it, but [discuss] something else of this nature.

Those who wish to go into the matter may do so by looking it up in the *Samantapāsādika*, the Vinaya Commentary.

"Having abandoned" means having abandoned this bad conduct ( *dussīlyaṃ*), known as the thought of killing living beings ( *pāṇātipātacetanāsaṅkhātaṃ*).

"Abstaining" means truly abstaining from that bad conduct, beginning from the time of abandoning it.

"There is no thought of transgressing" means that, just as with physical actions, the meaning should be understood in the same way in other such passages with regard to things cognizable by the eye and ear.

*Samaṇa* means the Blessed One ( *bhagavā*) who has gained the designation because he has calmed evil ( *samitapāpatāya laddhavohāro*).

*Gotama* [is used] because of [his] lineage ( *gottavasena*).

It is not only the Blessed One ( *bhagavāyeva*) who abstains from killing living beings (*pāṇātipātā paṭivirato*), but the community of monks ( *bhikkhusaṅghopi*) also abstains ( *paṭivirato*). The teaching ( *desanā*) has come thus from the beginning ( *ādito paṭṭhāya evaṃ āgatā*), but it is fitting for one who is explaining the meaning ( *atthaṃ pana dīpentena*) to also explain it in terms of the community of monks ( *bhikkhusaṅghavasenāpi dīpetuṃ vaṭṭati*).

"Having laid down the stick, having laid down the weapon" means that the meaning is "because he does not wield a stick or weapon to harm others, he has laid down the stick and laid down the weapon".

Here, it should be understood that after setting aside the stick ( *daṇḍaṃ*), all the remaining equipment ( *avasesaṃ upakaraṇaṃ*) is a weapon ( *sattham*) because it has the nature of harming beings ( *sattānaṃ viheṭhanabhāvato satthanti veditabbaṃ*).

But that which monks, having taken a knife, a tooth-stick, an axe, or a razor, wander about with, that is not for harming others ( *parūpaghātatthāya*).

Therefore, he is called one who has laid down the stick, who has laid down the weapon ( *nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho*).

"Conscientious" ( *lajjīti*) means possessed of conscientiousness ( *lajjāya samannāgato*) characterized by disgust for evil ( *pāpajigucchanalakkhaṇāya*).

"Compassionate" means one who has attained compassion ( *dayaṃ āpanno*) and a mind of loving-kindness ( *mettacittataṃ*).

"Having compassion for the welfare of all living beings" means he is compassionate with a mind to benefit all living beings ( *sabbe pāṇabhūte hitena anukampako*).

The meaning is that through this attainment of compassion ( *dayāpannatāya*), there is a mind to benefit all living beings ( *sabbesaṃ pāṇabhūtānaṃ hitacittakoti attho*).

"Dwells" means poses, moves, guards, persists, carries on, lives, dwells ( *iriyati yapeti yāpeti pāleti*).

Thus, or indeed, monks.

The word "or" is said to be used above in the sense of option, having considered "Having abandoned taking what is not given", etc. Thus, everywhere, the nature of option should be understood having considered what comes before or what comes after.

Now, here is a summary: Monks, when a worldling ( *puthujjano*) speaks the praise ( *vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno*) of the Tathāgata ( *Tathāgatassa*), he would say thus: "The ascetic ( *samaṇo*) Gotama does not kill ( *na hanati*) a living being ( *pāṇaṃ*), nor does he cause [another] to kill ( *na ghāteti*), nor does he approve ( *na tattha samanuñño hoti*) of it. He abstains ( *virato*) from this evil conduct ( *imasmā dussīlyā*). Oh, how great are the qualities of the Buddha ( *buddhaguṇā mahantā*)!" Thus, having made a great effort ( *mahantaṃ ussāhaṃ katvā*), even though he wishes to speak praise ( *vaṇṇaṃ vattukāmopi*), he would only speak ( *vakkhati*) of a trifling and insignificant amount ( *appamattakaṃ oramattakaṃ*)—mere virtue and [good] conduct ( *ācārasīlamattakameva*).

Relying upon the extraordinary qualities above ( *upari asādhāraṇabhāvaṃ nissāya*), he will not be able to speak praise ( *vaṇṇaṃ vattuṃ na sakkhissati*).

It is not only the worldling ( *puthujjanova*), but even stream-enterers ( *sotāpanna*), once-returners ( *sakadāgāmi*), non-returners ( *anāgāmi*), *arhats* ( *arahanto*) and even *paccekabuddhas* ( *paccekabuddhāpi*) are not able ( *na sakkonti*). Only the *Tathāgata* ( *Tathāgatoyeva*) is able ( *sakkoti*). We will speak of that above ( *taṃ vo upari vakkhāmi*). This is a meaningful explanation ( *ayamettha sādhippāyā atthavaṇṇanā*).

From here on ( *ito paraṃ pana*) we will explain only the words that have not been explained previously ( *apubbapadameva vaṇṇayissāma*).

In "Having abandoned taking what is not given" ( *adinnādānaṃ pahāyāti*), taking what is not given ( *adinnassa ādānaṃ*) is *adinnādāna*, the carrying off of another’s goods ( *parasaṃharaṇaṃ*), stealing ( *theyyaṃ*), robbery ( *corikāti vuttaṃ hoti*).

There ( *tattha*), "what is not given" ( *adinnanti*) is what is possessed by another ( *parapariggahitaṃ*), where another person, exercising free control as he wishes ( *yathākāmakāritaṃ āpajjanto*), is neither liable to punishment nor blame ( *adaṇḍāraho anupavajjo ca hoti*).

In the case of that which is possessed by another ( *tasmiṃ parapariggahite*), the volition of theft ( *theyyacetanā*) in one who perceives it as possessed by another ( *parapariggahitasaññino*), which initiates activity resulting in the taking of that thing ( *tadādāyakaupakkamasamuṭṭhāpikā*), is "taking what is not given" ( *adinnādānaṃ*).

That ( *taṃ* ) is less blameworthy ( *appasāvajjaṃ*) in the case of another's property of low value ( *hīne parasantake*), and more blameworthy ( *mahāsāvajjaṃ*) when it is of high value ( *paṇīte*). Why? Because of the value of the object ( *vatthupaṇītatāya*).

When the objects are equal in value ( *vatthusamatte sati*), the act is more blameworthy ( *mahāsāvajjaṃ*) when the object belongs to one of outstanding qualities ( *guṇādhikānaṃ santake vatthusmiṃ*).

Taking that very thing ( *taṃ taṃ*) from one with superior qualities ( *guṇādhikaṃ upādāya*), the act is less blameworthy ( *appasāvajjaṃ*) when the object belongs to one of inferior qualities ( *hīnaguṇassa santake vatthusmiṃ*) compared to that ( *tato tato*).

There are five components of this ( *tassa pañca sambhārā honti*): property belonging to another ( *parapariggahitaṃ*), the perception of the property belonging to another as such ( *parapariggahitasaññitā*), the thought of stealing ( *theyyacittaṃ*), the act ( *upakkamo*), and the removal of the article ( *tena haraṇanti*).
There are six means: one's own person, etc. ( *sāhatthikādayova*).
And these may be classified, according to the way in which they occur, by way of the following: taking by theft (*theyyāvahāro*), by force (*pasayhāvahāro*), by concealment (*paṭicchannāvahāro*), by stratagem (*parikappāvahāro*), by fraud (*kusāvahāro*). This here is in brief (*ayamettha saṅkhepo*).
The details, however, are given in the Samantapasadika.
"He takes only what is given," therefore he is a taker of what is given (*dinnādāyī*).
"Even with his mind, he only anticipates what has been given," therefore, he is one who anticipates only what has been given (*dinnapāṭikaṅkhī*).
*Theṇa* means a thief (*theno*).
Not by theft, by non-theft (*athenena*).
Indeed, through non-theft, he abides in purity (*sucibhūtena*).
*Attanā* means by way of self-nature (*attabhāvena*).
It is said that by making that non-theft the pure self, he dwells (in purity) (*athenaṃ sucibhūtaṃ attānaṃ katvā viharatīti vuttaṃ hoti*).
The remainder should be connected in the same way as stated in the first precept (*sesaṃ paṭhamasikkhāpade vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ*).
And as in this case, so with all (*yathā ca idha, evaṃ sabbattha*).
*Abrahmacariya* means uncelibate conduct (*aseṭṭhacariyaṃ*).
One who practices the highest conduct, the *brahma*, is a *brahmacārī*.
*Ārācārī* means one who keeps far from uncelibate conduct (*abrahmacariyato dūracārī*).
*Methuna* means unrighteous practices (*asaddhammā*) that have attained the designation *methuna*, because they are similar due to being overcome by passion (*rāgapariyuṭṭhānavasena sadisattā methunakāti*), and because they should be avoided by those who have obtained the designation.
*Gāmadhamma* means the practices of village dwellers (*gāmavāsīnaṃ dhammā*).

mula_pali: 9. ‘‘‘Musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo saccavādī saccasandho theto ṭheto (syā. kaṃ.) paccayiko avisaṃvādako lokassā’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya. ‘‘‘Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo, ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā amūsaṃ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā, sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī  samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya. ‘‘‘Pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo, yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya. ‘‘‘Samphappalāpaṃ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṃ  pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhita’nti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english:
9. “Having abandoned false speech ( *musāvādaṃ pahāya*), the recluse Gotama abstains from false speech. He speaks truth ( *saccavādī*), is devoted to truth ( *saccasandho*), is reliable (*theto*), trustworthy (*paccayiko*), and not a deceiver (*avisaṃvādako*) of the world." Thus, the ordinary person ( *puthujjano*) might speak in praise of the Tathāgata ( *tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno*).

“Having abandoned malicious speech (*pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya*), the recluse Gotama abstains from malicious speech. He does not repeat there what he has heard here to cause division among these people; or repeat here what he has heard there to cause division among those people.

Thus, he is a reconciler of those who are divided ( *bhinnānaṃ sandhātā*), and a promoter of friendships ( *sahitānaṃ anuppadātā*). Rejoicing in concord (*samaggārāmo*), delighting in concord ( *samaggarato*), exulting in concord (*samagganandī*), he speaks only words that create concord ( *samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā*)." Thus, the ordinary person might speak in praise of the Tathāgata.

“Having abandoned harsh speech (*pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya*), the recluse Gotama abstains from harsh speech. He speaks only such words as are gentle (*nelā*), pleasing to the ear ( *kaṇṇasukhā*), endearing ( *pemanīyā*), going to the heart (*hadayaṅgamā*), urbane (*porī*), amiable (*bahujanakantā*), and agreeable to many people ( *bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā*)." Thus, the ordinary person might speak in praise of the Tathāgata.

“Having abandoned idle chatter (*samphappalāpaṃ pahāya*), the recluse Gotama abstains from idle chatter. He speaks at the right time ( *kālavādī*), speaks what is factual ( *bhūtavādī*), speaks what is beneficial ( *atthavādī*), speaks of the Dharma ( *dhammavādī*), and the Discipline ( *vinayavādī*). His words are worth treasuring ( *nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā*): they are timely, backed by reason (*sāpadesaṃ*), definite, and connected with the goal ( *atthasaṃhita’nti*)." Thus, the ordinary person might speak in praise of the Tathāgata.
commentary_pali: 9.Musāvādaṃ pahāyāti ettha musāti visaṃvādanapurekkhārassa atthabhañjanako vacīpayogo kāyapayogo, vā visaṃvādanādhippāyena panassa paravisaṃvādakakāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādo. Aparo nayo, ‘musā’ti abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ vatthu. ‘Vādo’ti tassa bhūtato tacchato viññāpanaṃ. Lakkhaṇato pana atathaṃ vatthuṃ tathato paraṃ viññāpetukāmassa tathāviññattisamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādo. So yamatthaṃ bhañjati, tassa appatāya appasāvajjo, mahantatāya mahāsāvajjo. Api ca gahaṭṭhānaṃ attano santakaṃ adātukāmatāya natthītiādinayappavatto appasāvajjo, sakkhinā hutvā atthabhañjanatthaṃ vutto mahāsāvajjo, pabbajitānaṃ appakampi telaṃ vā sappiṃ vā labhitvā hasādhippāyena – ‘‘ajja gāme telaṃ nadī maññe sandatī’’ti pūraṇakathānayena  pavatto appasāvajjo, adiṭṭhaṃyeva pana diṭṭhantiādinā nayena vadantānaṃ mahāsāvajjo. Tassa cattāro sambhārā honti – atathaṃ vatthu, visaṃvādanacittaṃ, tajjo vāyāmo, parassa tadatthavijānananti. Eko payogo sāhatthikova. So kāyena vā kāyapaṭibaddhena vā vācāya  vā paravisaṃvādanakiriyākaraṇena daṭṭhabbo. Tāya ce kiriyāya paro tamatthaṃ jānāti, ayaṃ kiriyasamuṭṭhāpikacetanākkhaṇeyeva musāvādakammunā bajjhati. Yasmā  pana yathā kāyakāyapaṭibaddhavācāhi paraṃ visaṃvādeti, tathā ‘‘idamassa bhaṇāhī’’ti āṇāpentopi paṇṇaṃ likhitvā purato nissajjantopi, ‘‘ayamattho evaṃ daṭṭhabbo’’ti kuḍḍādīsu likhitvā ṭhapentopi. Tasmā ettha āṇattikanissaggiyathāvarāpi payogā yujjanti, aṭṭhakathāsu pana anāgatattā vīmaṃsitvā gahetabbā. Saccaṃ vadatīti saccavādī. Saccena saccaṃ sandahati ghaṭetīti saccasandho. Na antarantarā musā vadatīti attho. Yo hi puriso kadāci musā vadati, kadāci saccaṃ, tassa musāvādena antaritattā saccaṃ saccena na ghaṭīyati; tasmā so na saccasandho. Ayaṃ pana na tādiso, jīvitahetupi musā avatvā saccena saccaṃ sandahati yevāti saccasandho. Thetoti thiro thirakathoti attho. Eko hi puggalo haliddirāgo viya, thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇu viya, assapiṭṭhe ṭhapitakumbhaṇḍamiva ca na thirakatho hoti, eko pāsāṇalekhā viya, indakhīlo viya ca thirakatho hoti, asinā sīsaṃ chindantepi dve kathā na katheti, ayaṃ vuccati theto. Paccayikoti pattiyāyitabbako, saddhāyitabbakoti attho. Ekacco hi puggalo na paccayiko hoti, ‘‘idaṃ kena vuttaṃ, asukenā’’ti vutte ‘‘mā tassa vacanaṃ saddahathā’’ti vattabbataṃ āpajjati. Eko paccayiko hoti, ‘‘idaṃ kena vuttaṃ, asukenā’’ti vutte ‘‘yadi tena vuttaṃ, idameva pamāṇaṃ, idāni upaparikkhitabbaṃ natthi, evameva ida’’nti vattabbataṃ āpajjati, ayaṃ vuccati paccayiko. Avisaṃvādako lokassāti tāya saccavāditāya lokaṃ na visaṃvādetīti attho. Pisuṇaṃvācaṃ pahāyātiādīsu yāya vācāya yassa taṃ vācaṃ  bhāsati, tassa hadaye attano piyabhāvaṃ, parassa ca suññabhāvaṃ karoti, sā pisuṇā vācā. Yāya pana attānampi parampi pharusaṃ karoti, yā vācā sayampi pharusā, neva kaṇṇasukhā na hadayaṅgamā, ayaṃ pharusā vācā. Yena  samphaṃ palapati niratthakaṃ, so samphappalāpo. Tesaṃ mūlabhūtā cetanāpi pisuṇavācādināmeva labhati, sā eva ca idhādhippetāti. Tattha saṃkiliṭṭhacittassa paresaṃ vā bhedāya attano piyakamyatāya vā kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā pisuṇavācā. Sā yassa bhedaṃ karoti, tassa appaguṇatāya appasāvajjā, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjā. Tassā cattāro sambhārā – bhinditabbo paro, ‘‘iti ime nānā bhavissanti, vinā bhavissantī’’ti bhedapurekkhāratā vā, ‘‘iti ahaṃ piyo bhavissāmi vissāsiko’’ti piyakamyatā vā, tajjo vāyāmo, tassa tadatthavijānananti. Imesaṃ bhedāyāti, yesaṃ itoti vuttānaṃ santike sutaṃ tesaṃ bhedāya. Bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātāti dvinnaṃ mittānaṃ vā samānupajjhāyakādīnaṃ vā kenacideva kāraṇena bhinnānaṃ ekamekaṃ upasaṅkamitvā ‘‘tumhākaṃ īdise kule jātānaṃ evaṃ bahussutānaṃ idaṃ na yutta’’ntiādīni vatvā sandhānaṃ kattā anukattā. Anuppadātāti sandhānānuppadātā. Dve jane samagge disvā – ‘‘tumhākaṃ evarūpe kule jātānaṃ evarūpehi guṇehi samannāgatānaṃ anucchavikameta’’ntiādīni vatvā daḷhīkammaṃ kattāti attho. Samaggo ārāmo assāti samaggārāmo. Yattha samaggā natthi, tattha vasitumpi na icchatīti attho. Samaggarāmotipi pāḷi, ayamevettha attho. Samaggaratoti samaggesu rato, te pahāya aññattha gantumpi na icchatīti attho. Samagge disvāpi sutvāpi nandatīti samagganandī,samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitāti yā vācā satte samaggeyeva karoti , taṃ sāmaggiguṇaparidīpikameva vācaṃ bhāsati, na itaranti. Parassa  mammacchedakakāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā ekantapharusacetanā pharusāvācā. Tassā āvibhāvatthamidaṃ vatthu – eko kira dārako mātuvacanaṃ anādiyitvā araññaṃ gacchati, taṃ mātā nivattetumasakkontī – ‘‘caṇḍā taṃ mahiṃsī anubandhatū’’ti akkosi. Athassa tatheva araññe mahiṃsī  uṭṭhāsi. Dārako ‘‘yaṃ mama mātā mukhena kathesi, taṃ mā hotu, yaṃ cittena cintesi taṃ hotū’’ti, saccakiriyamakāsi. Mahiṃsī tattheva baddhā viya aṭṭhāsi. Evaṃ mammacchedakopi payogo cittasaṇhatāya na pharusā vācā hoti. Mātāpitaro hi kadāci puttake evaṃ vadanti – ‘‘corā vo khaṇḍākhaṇḍaṃ karontū’’ti, uppalapattampi ca nesaṃ upari patantaṃ na icchanti. Ācariyupajjhāyā ca kadāci nissitake evaṃ vadanti – ‘‘kiṃ ime ahirīkā anottappino caranti, niddhamatha ne’’ti, atha ca nesaṃ āgamādhigamasampattiṃ icchanti. Yathā ca cittasaṇhatāya pharusā vācā na hoti, evaṃ vacanasaṇhatāya apharusā vācā na hoti. Na hi mārāpetukāmassa – ‘‘imaṃ sukhaṃ sayāpethā’’ti vacanaṃ apharusā vācā hoti, cittapharusatāya panesā pharusā vācāva. Sā yaṃ sandhāya pavattitā, tassa appaguṇatāya appasāvajjā, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjā. Tassā tayo sambhārā – akkositabbo paro, kupitacittaṃ, akkosanāti. Nelāti elaṃ vuccati doso, nāssā elanti nelā, niddosāti attho. ‘‘Nelaṅgo setapacchādo’’ti, (udā. 65) ettha vuttanelaṃ viya. Kaṇṇasukhāti byañjanamadhuratāya kaṇṇānaṃ sukhā, sūcivijjhanaṃ viya kaṇṇasūlaṃ na janeti. Atthamadhuratāya sakalasarīre kopaṃ ajanetvā pemaṃ janetīti pemanīyā. Hadayaṃ gacchati, appaṭihaññamānā sukhena cittaṃ pavisatīti hadayaṅgamā.  Guṇaparipuṇṇatāya pure bhavāti porī pure saṃvaḍḍhanārī  viya sukumārātipi porī. Purassa esātipi porī. Nagaravāsīnaṃ kathāti attho. Nagaravāsino hi yuttakathā honti. Pitimattaṃ pitāti vadanti, bhātimattaṃ bhātāti vadanti, mātimattaṃ mātāti vadanti. Evarūpī kathā bahuno janassa kantā hotīti bahujanakantā. Kantabhāveneva bahuno janassa manāpā cittavuḍḍhikarāti bahujanamanāpā. Anatthaviññāpikā kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā akusalacetanā samphappalāpo. So āsevanamandatāya appasāvajjo, āsevanamahantatāya mahāsāvajjo, tassa dve sambhārā – bhāratayuddhasītāharaṇādiniratthakakathāpurekkhāratā, tathārūpī kathā kathanañca. Kālena  vadatīti kālavādī vattabbayuttakālaṃ sallakkhetvā vadatīti attho. Bhūtaṃ tathaṃ tacchaṃ  sabhāvameva vadatīti bhūtavādī.  Diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikatthasannissitameva katvā vadatīti atthavādī. Navalokuttaradhammasannissitaṃ katvā vadatīti dhammavādī saṃvaravinayapahānavinayasannissitaṃ katvā vadatīti vinayavādī. Nidhānaṃ vuccati ṭhapanokāso, nidhānamassā atthīti nidhānavatī. Hadaye nidhātabbayuttakaṃ vācaṃ bhāsitāti attho. Kālenāti evarūpiṃ bhāsamānopi ca – ‘‘ahaṃ nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsissāmī’’ti na akālena bhāsati, yuttakālaṃ pana apekkhitvāva bhāsatīti attho. Sāpadesanti saupamaṃ, sakāraṇanti attho. Pariyantavatinti paricchedaṃ dassetvā yathāssā paricchedo paññāyati, evaṃ bhāsatīti attho. Atthasaṃhitanti  anekehipi nayehi vibhajantena pariyādātuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya atthasampannaṃ bhāsati. Yaṃ vā so atthavādī atthaṃ vadati, tena atthena sahitattā atthasaṃhitaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati, na aññaṃ nikkhipitvā aññaṃ bhāsatīti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
9. Having abandoned false speech, here, *musā* (falsehood) is vocal or bodily effort destroying the welfare of others, preceded by deception. "False speech" is the volition with the intention to deceive, which brings about bodily or vocal effort to deceive others.

Another method: "False" (*musā*) means an unreal, untrue case (*abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ vatthu*).

"Speech" (*vādo*) is the communication of that as being real, true.

According to characteristic, "false speech" is the volition of one desiring to communicate to another an untrue case as being true, which initiates such an act of communication.

This is less blameworthy when the welfare destroyed is slight, and more blameworthy when the welfare destroyed is great.

Further, when a householder, reluctant to part with a certain possession, denies that he owns it, it is of little blame; but when he is called to witness and lies for the sake of destroying another’s welfare, then the blame is heavy. For monks, the blame is light when they exaggerate in jest, e. g. , if after getting a little oil or ghee they say, “Oil flows like a river in the village today.” But the blame is heavy when they claim to have seen something they did not see.

There are four constituents of this act: an untrue case (*atathaṃ vatthu*), the mind to deceive (*visaṃvādanacittaṃ*), the appropriate effort (*tajjo vāyāmo*), the communicating of that meaning to another (*parassa tadatthavijānananti*).

There is one means, one’s own person only (*eko प्रयोगो साहत्थिकोव*).

That is to be regarded as the performing of the action of deceiving another by means of the body or by means of something attached to the body or by means of speech.

If, through that action, the other understands that meaning, one is bound by the *kamma* of false speech at the very moment of the volition initiating the action.

Since one deceives another through body, or through something attached to the body, or through speech, so too, one deceives another by ordering, "Tell him this!”, or by writing a document, or by placing something in front [of someone], or by writing on walls and so on, "This meaning is to be regarded thus."

Therefore, here, applications such as command, relinquishment, and firmness are fitting. However, in the commentaries, because it is not in the future, it should be considered and taken up.

Speaking truth (*saccaṃ vadatīti*) is the truth-speaker (*saccavādī*).

He connects truth with truth and brings it about, therefore he is truth-connected (*saccasandho*).

The meaning is that he does not speak falsehood intermittently (*na antarantarā musā vadatīti attho*).

For if a person sometimes speaks falsehood and sometimes speaks truth, because truth is interrupted by falsehood, truth is not connected with truth; therefore, he is not truth-connected (*na saccasandho*).

But this person is not like that; even for the sake of his life, he does not speak falsehood, and he connects truth with truth; therefore, he is truth-connected (*saccasandho*).

*Theto* means firm; the meaning is one with firm speech (*thiro thirakathoti attho*).

For one person, like turmeric dye, or like a stake stuck in a heap of chaff, or like a gourd placed on a donkey's back, is not one with firm speech; another person, like a line on a stone, or like Indra's post, is one with firm speech. Even if his head is cut off with a sword, he does not speak two speeches; this is called firm (*theto*).

Trustworthy (*paccayiko*) means one who should be trusted, one who should be believed; this is the meaning.

For one person is not trustworthy; when it is said, "This was spoken by whom? By so-and-so," he incurs the condition of being spoken to [by others], "Do not trust his word".

One person is trustworthy; when it is said, “This was spoken by whom? By so-and-so,” he incurs the condition of being spoken to [by others], “If it was spoken by him, this is indeed the measure; now there is no need to examine it; it is just like this.” This one is called trustworthy (*paccayiko*).

He does not deceive the world; the meaning is that, by means of that truth-speaking, he does not deceive the world (*avisaṃvādako lokassāti tāya saccavāditāya lokaṃ na visaṃvādetīti attho*).

Having abandoned malicious speech (*pisuṇaṃvācaṃ pahāya*), etc.: The kind of speech that creates in the heart of the person to whom it is spoken affection for oneself and voidness for another is malicious speech (*sā pisuṇā vācā*).

The kind of speech by which one makes both oneself and another harsh, the kind of speech which is also itself harsh, being pleasant neither to the ear nor to the heart — that is harsh speech (*pharusā vācā*).

That by which one gossips idly, without meaning, is gossip (*samphappalāpo*).

Also, the volition that is the root cause of these gains the name “malicious speech,” etc. And that only is intended here (*idhādhippetāti*).

Therein, malicious speech is the volition of one with a defiled mind (*saṃkiliṭṭhacittassa*), which initiates an effort by body or by speech either to cause division among others or to endear oneself.

The act is less blameworthy when the person one divides has few good qualities, and more blameworthy when such a one has great qualities.

Its constituents are four: another person to be divided, the intention to divide, “Thus these will be separated and split” or the desire to endear oneself, “Thus I shall become loved and intimate,” the appropriate effort, the communicating of that meaning to that person.

"For division of these": it is for the division of those to whom it has been said and who have heard it in their presence.

"Or uniting those who are divided": the doer and instigator is one who approaches each of two friends or those with a common teacher etc. who have been divided for some reason or other, and says, "This is not right for you who were born in such a family and are so learned" etc., and makes a connection.

Non-giving of connection means the non-bestowal of connection (*sandhānānuppadātā*).

Having seen two united people, and having said - "This is unbecoming for you who are born in such a family, who are endowed with such qualities" etc., the meaning is that he is the doer of firm action (*daḷhīkammaṃ kattāti attho*).

A park is united to him, therefore it is a united park (*samaggārāmo*).

The meaning is that he does not wish to live where there is no unity (*yattha samaggā natthi, tattha vasitumpi na icchatīti attho*).

*Samaggarāmotipi* is the *pāḷi*, this itself is the meaning here.

"Delighting in unity" means one who delights in those who are united; he does not wish to go elsewhere, having abandoned them; this is the meaning.

He delights, having seen or heard those who are united, therefore, he is one who delights in unity (*samagganandī*). Speaking speech that makes for unity (*samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitāti*): that speech which makes beings completely united, that speech speaks only of making clear the quality of unity, not another.
Harsh speech is an entirely harsh thought that arises from an action of wounding the vital feelings of another through bodily or vocal means.

This is an example given for the purpose of making it clear: A village boy, it is said, went to the forest without heeding his mother’s words. Unable to make him turn back, she scolded him angrily, saying: “May a wild buffalo chase you!”

Then a buffalo appeared before him right there in the forest.

The boy made an asseveration of truth, saying: “Let it not be as my mother said but as she thought!”

The buffalo stood as though tied there.

Thus, although the means was that of wounding the vital feelings, because of the gentleness of her mind it was not harsh speech.

For parents sometimes tell their children: “May robbers cut you into bits!” But in truth they do not want even a lotus leaf to fall on them.

And preceptors and teachers sometimes say to their pupils: “What is the use with you shameless rascals. Get out!” Yet they wish their success in study and spiritual achievement.

Just as, through gentleness of mind, speech is not harsh, so through gentleness of speech, speech does not become unharsh.

For the words “Let him sleep in peace” spoken by one wishing to kill are not unharsh speech, but because of harshness of mind it is indeed harsh speech.

It is less blameworthy when the person to whom it is spoken has few good qualities, and more blameworthy when such a one has great qualities.

Its constituents are three: another to be abused, an angry mind, the abusing.

"Nela" means "fault" (*doṣa*). Because there is no *ela* in it, it is *nela*, meaning without fault (*nirdoṣa*).

For example, “*nelaṅgo setapacchādo*”.

(65) Here, it is like *nela* that was spoken.

"Pleasing to the ear" (*kaṇṇasukha*) means pleasing to the ears because of the sweetness of the consonants. It does not produce ear-pain like being pierced by a needle.

"Arousing affection" (*pemanīya*) means that it arouses affection by not producing anger in the whole body because of the sweetness of the meaning.

"Grasping the heart" (*hadayaṅgama*) means that it goes to the heart and enters the mind pleasantly without being resisted.

"Noble" (*porī*) means that it is perfect in virtue, comes to be in the city, is tender like a woman brought up in the city.

It is "noble" (*porī*) because it is of the city.

It means the speech of city-dwellers.

For city-dwellers have speech that is appropriate.

They call one who has only affection "father" (*pitā*), they call one who has only brightness "brother" (*bhātā*), they call one who has only measuring "mother" (*mātā*).

Because speech of such a kind is pleasing to many people, it is "pleasing to many people" (*bahujanakantā*).

Because it is pleasing to the mind and increases thought for many people just through its state of being pleasing, it is "agreeable to many people" (*bahujanamanāpā*).

Having abandoned idle chatter “Idle chatter” is the unwholesome volition occasioning the bodily or vocal effort to communicate something useless.

It is less blameworthy when indulgence is mild, more blameworthy when indulgence is great. There are two components: the disposition to engage in useless talk, such us talk on the great war of India or the abduction of Sītā, and the act of engaging in such talk.

"Speaking at the right time" (*kālavādī*) means that he speaks after considering the appropriate time for speaking.

"Speaking the truth" (*bhūtavādī*) means that he speaks of what is true, factual, and in accordance with reality.

"Speaking with a purpose" (*atthavādī*) means that he speaks having relied only on the benefits of what is visible in this life and what will arise in future lives.

"Speaking the Dharma" (*dhammavādī*) means that he speaks having relied on the nine supramundane *dharmas*. "Speaking the Vinaya" (*vinayavādī*) means that he speaks having relied on restraint, discipline, and abandonment discipline.

"Treasure" (*nidhāna*) means a place for storing. Because there is a store in her, she is "treasure-filled" (*nidhānavatī*).

It means that she speaks speech that is appropriate for storing in the heart.

Because he always shines with timeliness, he does not speak out of season saying, “I will speak speech filled with treasure” but rather, he speaks only after giving consideration to what is the right time.

"With a pretext" (*sāpadesa*) means with a simile (*saupama*), meaning with a reason (*sakāraṇa*).

"Having a limit" (*pariyantavatinti*) means that after showing a demarcation, he speaks in such a way that its demarcation is understood.

"Connected with meaning" (*atthasaṃhita*) means that because it is impossible to fully express it with many different means, he speaks speech endowed with meaning.

Or, because that speaker of meaning (*atthavādī*) speaks with meaning (*attha*), through being connected with that meaning, he speaks speech connected with meaning (*atthasaṃhita*). It has been said that he does not set aside one thing and speak of another.

mula_pali: 10. ‘Bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā samārabbhā (sī. ka.) paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave…pe…. ‘‘‘Ekabhattiko samaṇo gotamo rattūparato virato paṭivirato (katthaci) vikālabhojanā…. Naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā naccagītavāditavisukadassanā (ka.) paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Mālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Jātarūparajatapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Āmakamaṃsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Itthikumārikapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Dāsidāsapaṭiggahaṇā  paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Ajeḷakapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Kukkuṭasūkarapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Hatthigavassavaḷavapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Khettavatthupaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Kayavikkayā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Tulākūṭakaṃsakūṭamānakūṭā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Ukkoṭanavañcananikatisāciyogā sāviyogā (syā. kaṃ. ka.) paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…. Chedanavadhabandhanaviparāmosaālopasahasākārā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english:
10. ‘The recluse Gotama abstains from damaging seed and plant life.
‘The recluse Gotama takes only one meal a day, abstaining from food at night and from eating at improper times.
The recluse Gotama abstains from watching dancing, singing, music, and shows.
The recluse Gotama abstains from wearing garlands, embellishing himself with scents, and beautifying himself with unguents.
The recluse Gotama abstains from using high and luxurious beds.
The recluse Gotama abstains from accepting gold and silver (jātarūparajatapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…).
The recluse Gotama abstains from accepting uncooked grain.
The recluse Gotama abstains from accepting raw meat.
The recluse Gotama abstains from accepting women and girls.
The recluse Gotama abstains from accepting male and female slaves.
The recluse Gotama abstains from accepting goats and sheep (ajeḷakapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…).
The recluse Gotama abstains from accepting fowl and swine.
The recluse Gotama abstains from accepting elephants, cattle, horses, and mares.
The recluse Gotama abstains from accepting fields and lands (khettavatthupaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…).
The recluse Gotama abstains from going as a messenger or errand-runner.
The recluse Gotama abstains from buying and selling.
The recluse Gotama abstains from cheating with false weights and measures (tulākūṭakaṃsakūṭamānakūṭā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…).
The recluse Gotama abstains from bribery and corruption, deception and insincerity (ukkoṭanavañcananikatisāciyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo…).
The recluse Gotama abstains from wounding, killing, imprisoning, highway robbery, and taking food by force.’ “It is in this way, bhikkhus, that the worldling would speak when speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*.
commentary_pali: 10.Bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhāti mūlabījaṃ khandhabījaṃ phaḷubījaṃ aggabījaṃ bījabījanti pañcavidhassa bījagāmassa ceva, yassa kassaci nīlatiṇarukkhādikassa bhūtagāmassa ca samārambhā, chedanabhedanapacanādibhāvena vikopanā paṭiviratoti attho. Ekabhattikoti pātarāsabhattaṃ sāyamāsabhattanti dve bhattāni, tesu pātarāsabhattaṃ antomajjhanhikena paricchinnaṃ, itaraṃ majjhanhikato uddhaṃ anto aruṇena. Tasmā antomajjhanhike dasakkhattuṃ bhuñjamānopi ekabhattikova hoti. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ ‘‘ekabhattiko’’ti. Rattiyā bhojanaṃ ratti, tato uparatoti rattūparato. Atikkante majjhanhike yāva sūriyatthaṅgamanā bhojanaṃ vikālabhojanaṃ nāma. Tato viratattā virato vikālabhojanā. Kadā virato? Anomānadītīre pabbajitadivasato paṭṭhāya. Sāsanassa ananulomattā visūkaṃ paṭāṇībhūtaṃ dassananti visūkadassanaṃ. Attanā naccananaccāpanādivasena naccā ca gītā ca vāditā ca antamaso  mayūranaccādivasenapi pavattānaṃ naccādīnaṃ visūkabhūtā dassanā cāti naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā. Naccādīni hi attanā  payojetuṃ vā parehi payojāpetuṃ vā payuttāni passituṃ vā neva bhikkhūnaṃ na bhikkhunīnañca vaṭṭanti. Mālādīsu mālāti yaṃ kiñci pupphaṃ. Gandhanti yaṃ kiñci gandhajātaṃ. Vilepananti chavirāgakaraṇaṃ. Tattha piḷandhanto dhāreti nāma, ūnaṭṭhānaṃ pūrento maṇḍeti nāma, gandhavasena chavirāgavasena ca sādiyanto vibhūseti nāma. Ṭhānaṃ vuccati kāraṇaṃ. Tasmā yāya  dussīlyacetanāya tāni mālādhāraṇādīni mahājano karoti, tato paṭiviratoti attho. Uccāsayanaṃ vuccati pamāṇātikkantaṃ. Mahāsayananti akappiyapaccattharaṇaṃ. Tato viratoti attho. Jātarūpanti suvaṇṇaṃ. Rajatanti kahāpaṇo, lohamāsako, jatumāsako, dārumāsakoti ye vohāraṃ gacchanti. Tassa ubhayassāpi paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato, neva naṃ uggaṇhāti, na uggaṇhāpeti, na upanikkhittaṃ sādiyatīti attho. Āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇāti, sālivīhiyavagodhūmakaṅguvarakakudrūsakasaṅkhātassa sattavidhassāpi āmakadhaññassa paṭiggahaṇā. Na kevalañca etesaṃ paṭiggahaṇameva, āmasanampi bhikkhūnaṃ na vaṭṭatiyeva. Āmakamaṃsapaṭiggahaṇāti ettha aññatra odissa anuññātā āmakamaṃsamacchānaṃ paṭiggahaṇameva bhikkhūnaṃ na vaṭṭati, no āmasanaṃ. Itthikumārikapaṭiggahaṇāti ettha itthīti purisantaragatā, itarā kumārikā nāma, tāsaṃ paṭiggahaṇampi āmasanampi akappiyameva. Dāsidāsapaṭiggahaṇāti ettha dāsidāsavaseneva tesaṃ paṭiggahaṇaṃ na vaṭṭati. ‘‘Kappiyakārakaṃ dammi, ārāmikaṃ dammī’’ti evaṃ vutte pana vaṭṭati. Ajeḷakādīsu khettavatthupariyosānesu kappiyākappiyanayo vinayavasena upaparikkhitabbo. Tattha khettaṃ nāma yasmiṃ pubbaṇṇaṃ ruhati. Vatthu nāma yasmiṃ aparaṇṇaṃ ruhati. Yattha vā ubhayampi ruhati, taṃ khettaṃ. Tadatthāya  akatabhūmibhāgo vatthu.  Khettavatthusīsena cettha vāpitaḷākādīnipi saṅgahitāneva. Dūteyyaṃ vuccati dūtakammaṃ, gihīnaṃ pahitaṃ paṇṇaṃ vā sāsanaṃ vā gahetvā tattha tattha gamanaṃ. Pahiṇagamanaṃ vuccati gharā gharaṃ pesitassa khuddakagamanaṃ. Anuyogo nāma tadubhayakaraṇaṃ. Tasmā dūteyyapahiṇagamanānaṃ anuyogāti. Evamettha attho veditabbo. Kayavikkayāti kayā ca vikkayā ca. Tulākūṭādīsu kūṭanti vañcanaṃ. Tattha tulākūṭaṃ nāma rūpakūṭaṃ aṅgakūṭaṃ, gahaṇakūṭaṃ, paṭicchannakūṭanti catubbidhaṃ hoti. Tattha rūpakūṭaṃ nāma dve tulā samarūpā katvā gaṇhanto mahatiyā gaṇhāti, dadanto khuddikāya deti. Aṅgakūṭaṃ nāma gaṇhanto pacchābhāge hatthena tulaṃ akkamati, dadanto pubbabhāge. Gahaṇakūṭaṃ nāma gaṇhanto mūle rajjuṃ gaṇhāti, dadanto agge. Paṭicchannakūṭaṃ nāma tulaṃ susiraṃ katvā anto ayacuṇṇaṃ pakkhipitvā gaṇhanto taṃ pacchābhāge karoti, dadanto aggabhāge. Kaṃso vuccati suvaṇṇapāti, tāya vañcanaṃ kaṃsakūṭaṃ. Kathaṃ?
